urn:contentItem:5WG8-BTC1-JBG6-54VV-00000-00Walmart and giant US retailers turn up heat on Amazon and Google by calling for blockbuster antitrust investigation2019-07-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:41ZLexisNexisWalmart and giant US retailers turn up heat on Amazon and Google by calling for blockbuster antitrust investigationfeedback@businessinsider.com (Isobel Asher Hamilton)

The Retail Industry Leaders Association said antitrust laws should be adapted to accommodate big tech companies like Amazon, Google, and Facebook.

Getty; AP

An association of US retail giants, including Walmart, Target, and Best Buy, have backed calls for an antitrust investigation into Amazon and Google.

The Retail Industry Leaders Association wrote to the Federal Trade Commission with the demand, emphasising the dominance they have over consumer data.

The Association said Amazon raises "clear antitrust concerns" because of the way it amasses third-party sales data and sells its own products.

The retailers could be hoping to capitalize on the growing hostility towards big tech in Washington D.C.

Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories.

Some of the biggest retailers in America have thrown their weight behind antitrust investigations into Amazon and Google.

The Retail Industry Leaders Association (RILA), which counts Walmart, Target, and Best Buy among its members, wrote a 10-page letter to the Federal Trade Commission, saying it would be happy to assist with regulatory probes.

The letter, which is dated June 30, outlines how the Association believes antitrust laws need to be adapted to accommodate big tech companies like Amazon, Google, and Facebook.

In doing so, they could be hoping to capitalize on the growing hostility towards big tech in Washington D.C., where work is underway to investigate if the FAANG companies are abusing their market dominance.

"Our view is that modern antitrust enforcement needs to be driven by a greater recognition that control over information can drive anticompetitive effect just as much as market power and price control," RILA wrote.

One of the main concerns raised in the letter is to do with tech giants controlling how people search online. "It should... be quite concerning to the Commission that Amazon and Google control the majority of all of Internet product search, and can very easily affect whether and how price and product information actually reaches customers," the letter said.

RILA takes particular aim at Amazon for "degrad[ing] the consumer experience on its own platform," and said the company "tends to deceive consumers" by pretending to sell directly from trusted brands, even when those brands choose to remain off the platform and their merchandise is being sold on by third-party sellers.

Read more: Big tech's giant power could be challenged in blockbuster antitrust probes - here's what that means for Apple, Amazon, Facebook, and Google

The letter also raises concerns over Amazon's "anticompetitive uses of data." Specifically, it points out that Amazon both amasses third-party sales data and sells its own products, which RILA said poses "clear antitrust concerns because of the unique characteristics of such a platform."

Citing antitrust scholars at the University of Chicago, the letter said: "By selling logistics services to many of its sellers, Amazon gains an advantage when it wishes to launch a store brand. It can analyze data from its rivals to develop an entry plan against those sellers."

At the end of the letter, RILA said it "stands ready to work with the Commission." RILA's vice president of innovation Nicholas Ahrens reiterated this sentiment in an interview with Bloomberg.

"It's pretty clear to us that the FTC and different relevant regulators should be taking a much closer look at these platform companies," said Ahrens. "We are here to help."

The retailers' letter turns up the heat on rivals like Amazon. Democratic presidential hopeful Elizabeth Warren is among those to have said that Amazon's role as both marketplace and vendor is a prime reason for breaking up Jeff Bezos' company.

Last month, reports emerged that the FTC and the Department of Justice have divided up the big tech companies between them for antitrust scrutiny. The FTC is said to have responsibility for Facebook and Amazon, while the DOJ is getting Google and Apple.

Amazon and Google were not immediately available for comment when contacted by Business Insider.

It can analyze data from its rivals to develop an entry plan against those sellers." At the end of the letter, RILA said it "stands ready to work with the Commission." RILA's vice president of innovation Nicholas Ahrens reiterated this sentiment in an interview with Bloomberg[4]. "It's pretty clear to us that the FTC and different relevant regulators should be taking a much closer look at these platform companies," said Ahrens. "We are here to help." The retailers' letter turns up the heat on rivals like Amazon. Democratic presidential hopeful Elizabeth Warren is among those to have said that Amazon's role as both marketplace and vendor is a prime reason for breaking up Jeff Bezos' company[5]. Last month, reports emerged that the FTC and the Department of Justice have divided up the big tech companies[6] between them for antitrust scrutiny. The FTC is said to have responsibility for Facebook and Amazon, while the DOJ is getting Google and Apple. Oct 09, 2019( Axios: https://link.axios.com/join/am-signup?source=aci Delivered by Newstex) At a moment when regulators, politicians and consumers are railing against companies getting too big, one behemoth has been growing under the radar: Walmart.The big picture: Walmart already had its turn as the corporate villain in the 1980s. Now, as tech companies bear the brunt of the scrutiny, the retail giant is amassing wealth — earning $514.4 billion in revenue, the most of any company on Earth, in 2018.What's happening: "I don't think anyone is paying attention to Walmart," says Sally Hubbard, a director at the Open Markets Institute and a former assistant attorney general in New York's antitrust bureau. "It's just not on people's minds because it isn't considered the way of the future. ... The government sees brick and mortar as more of a dying industry."But Walmart isn't going anywhere.

It has transformed into a 21st-century company that's doing everything Amazon is doing — and it's neck-and-neck with Amazon in a few high-tech areas that are considered the tech giant's home turf, like drone delivery[1] and same-day shipping.Investigators are under intense political pressure from lawmakers and consumers to do something about Big Tech, says Hubbard. But "the political pressure just isn't there to investigate Walmart. The places where Walmart has large grocery market share are not places where policy activists live."Amazon is new to the U.S. grocery business, of which Walmart already owns 13%. In many parts of America, Walmart's dominance is far more pronounced. The retailer has more than 50% market share in 203 cities and towns, and more than 70% in 38 of those places, per a recent report[2] from the Institute for Local Self-Reliance (ILSR). Many of these towns are among the most economically distressed in the nation."No other grocer in the history of the country has ever had this kind of market share," says Stacy Mitchell, co-director at ILSR, a nonprofit research and advocacy group that opposes concentrated economic power.When it comes to all U.S. retail spending[3], Walmart takes 8.9% and Amazon 6.4%. Jeff Bezos has become the American billionaire archetype. But also consider the Walton family of Walmart fortune: six members of the family have more wealth than the bottom 41% of Americans.What to watch: Not only is Walmart avoiding the antitrust spotlight, but it is also helping fuel the techlash against its competitors. The Free and Fair Markets Institute, which called itself a "grassroots campaign" to topple Amazon, is funded by Walmart, reports WSJ[4].Walmart is also part of the Retail Industry Leaders Association that has written to the Federal Trade Commission and the Justice Department with concerns that Amazon and Google stifle competition, the LA Times reports[5]. Worth noting: A major driver of the global antitrust probes into Amazon is the fact that it simultaneously operates as an e-commerce platform and an individual seller — it's the mall, but it also has its own store within the mall, in the best location. Walmart's online platform isn't nearly as powerful as Amazon's. "When we ask sellers who are fed up with Amazon why they don't switch to Walmart.com, they say the volume just isn't there," Hubbard says. The bottom line: "The fad to hate Walmart has been overshadowed," says Eleanor Fox, an NYU antitrust law professor. urn:contentItem:5W2T-RYR1-DY0W-42J6-00000-00Wal-Mart, Microsoft Take Aim At Amazon With Cloud Tech; Microsoft CEO Calls For A.I. Regulation Of Facial Recognition Technology2018-07-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:41ZLexisNexisWal-Mart, Microsoft Take Aim At Amazon With Cloud Tech; Microsoft CEO Calls For A.I. Regulation Of Facial Recognition TechnologyLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good Tuesday morning. Welcome back, everybody. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Tuesday, July 17th. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. Taking on Amazon, Wal-Mart and Microsoft team up on a new cloud deal. Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella telling me in an exclusive interview why the partnership is crucial.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SATYA NADELLA, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, MICROSOFT: Everything that we think about, every places being digitized whether it's a retail outlet or a hospital, a stadium, your home or your workplace is increasingly comPuting, it's getting embedded in the real world. And in the case of Wal-Mart is a good example because if you think about Wal-Mart they have an amazing need today when it comes to anything around off-line commerce but they're increasing the momentum online.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: More of my exclusive interview with Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella straight ahead. Earnings in focus this morning on Wall Street. Three Dow components reporting their second quarter ahead of the opening bell. Johnson & Johnson, Goldman Sachs, and UnitedHealth are all out. Goldman Sachs President David Solomon will become CEO on October 1 according to the New York Times. The handoff to David Solomon was expected and now we know the date October 1 a change in leadership at Goldman Sachs. Markets this morning look like this, futures edging lower. The Dow Industrials now at the low of the morning here down about 30 points. The S&P 500 down three and the NASDAQ down 3-/2. This after the markets finished the day mixed yesterday. Take a look, Dow Industrials picked up 45 points but the S&P and the NASDAQ fractionally lower on the session.

And in Europe this morning, markets are lower across the board. The FT-100 down nine points, the CAC quarante down 25, that's a half of a percent. And the DAX Index in Germany down a quarter of a percent. In Asia overnight, mixed performances, take a look the best performer was Japan, Nikkei Average up one-half of one percent. Amazon prime day will under way but it got off to a rock start outages prevented customers from making purchases yesterday. The fallout for the retail giant on the biggest sales day of the year.

And it was a wild night at the Home Run Derby, Bryce Harper pulling off a last second win at his home stadium. We have all the highlights. All those stories coming up this Tuesday morning and joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, The Wall Street Journal global economics editor, Jon Hilsenrath and CFRA investment strategist, Lindsey Bell. Great show so far guys.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: Good to be here. And earnings are doing very, very well, 19.6 percent on the S&P 500. 90 percent of companies beating the bottom line.

BARTIROMO: And revenue?

BELL: And revenue, 87 percent finish top line.

BARTIROMO: Just for the second quarter.

BELL: Nine percent revenue.

JON HILSENRATH, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CONTRIBUTOR: The estimates are for earnings of 26 or 27 percent, isn't it?

BARTIROMO: Not second quarter.

(CROSSTALK)

BELL: the numbers --

(CROSSTALK)

HILSENRATH: -- getting better as the new numbers comes.

BARTIROMO: So you think the earnings period gets even better for the second quarter?

HILSENRATH: Could be.

BARTIROMO: All right. We're going to keep watching that. We want to look at Microsoft which is of course is reporting earnings later this week. It is teaming up with Wal-Mart to take on Amazon. The retail giant looking to accelerate its digital transformation with the help of Microsoft's cloud technology. I spoke exclusively with Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella for his take on the partnership, privacy concerns facing technology today and where Microsoft can continue to grow.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

NADELLA: The core mission of our company really comes through in the momentum we have. If you think about it, we sort of describe our mission as empowering every person in every organization on the planet to achieve more. In our words, our success, whatever we have of it is dependent on our costumers succeeding in an increasingly digital world. That's what you see what's on the examples like Wal-Mart who's patterned deeply with us and others.

BARTIROMO: It's interesting because this announcement with Wal-Mart, a strategic partnership, it's a digital transformation for Wal-Mart but you're calling this a 4-1/2 trillion opportunity. This transformation to digital.

NADELLA: Yes, it's actually frustration. If we think about it for all the success of digital technology companies on a percentage basis of the GDP, the worldwide GDP, I think the text banned is just around five percent. It is expected to go to 10 percent next 10 years. But the real question is, what is the opportunity for the other 95 percent of GDP or the 90 percent of the GDP. How are they going to use the digital technology, doing some sense digital companies in their own right. Whether it's any retailer like Wal-Mart or any health company, 81 across all industries is going to look to digital technology to bring about the next level of experience innovation or cost savings.

BARTIROMO: And for Wal-Mart, this is a critical transition as it battles with Amazon who of course, has been incredibly aggressive in that space. Tell me about I.T. budgets today. Are you seeing that increase in technology spending? I know that there was a pretty good lift when the tax plan first came out in anticipation of the tax cut plan but there was worries that things have slowed down. Are you still seeing I.T. budgets increase and are you seeing the kind of spend that you would expect?

NADELLA: No, I mean, on a long-term basis, if I had to sort of look at it, tax spend or digital spend is absolutely going to increase just because everything that we think about every place is being digitized whether it's a retail outlet or a hospital, a stadium, your home or your workplace is increasing comPuting, it's getting embedded in the real world. Every experience is being driven by more and more A.I. capability. So that's what's going to keep driving more tax spend. It's going to essentially -- I think over the world's operating expense as well as cogs are being digitized. And in the case of Wal-Mart is a good example because if you think about Wal-Mart, they're having amazing lead today when it comes to anything around off-line commerce. But they're increasing their momentum online.

BARTIROMO: Is the priority for companies today whether big or small, because let's not forget Microsoft is really the priority for smaller and midcap companies as well in addition to the G.E.s and the Wal-Marts of the world. But is the spend priority in terms of security right now or is it cloud? Where would you see the priority is in terms of corporate spending?

NADELLA: I would say the number one priority is around productivity and digital transformation.

BARTIROMO: Was it the tax cut plan that encouraged you to take some money back to the U.S.?

NADELLA: I mean, I think we've had a pretty balanced approach. First and foremost we are being very aggressive spenders in R&D dollars and operating expenses right here in the United States. And if you look at what we do, we do (INAUDIBLE) $30 plus billion spend every year, and majority 85 percent of it is right here in the United States. And so we continue to bet on the organic growth and innovation but we are complementing that, whether it's with LinkedIn or pending acquisition or GitHub or what you did earlier with Minecraft. We are looking for assets that can complement what we do well and as well as dividends and buybacks. So, we think having that approach which is some in some sense more stable across all various different forms and spend patterns in business cycles is important. But at at the end of the day what matters to us is continue to drive the innovation and growth in this company.

BARTIROMO: You have been in China for a long time and I have a stat here, someone said to me that there was expectation that 97 percent of companies in China use Microsoft Windows and more than 90 percent do not pay for it. You have been dealing with piracy this for a long time. What can you tell us about it?

NADELLA: I mean, I think one of the fundamental things that been -- have been our approach in China is to be able sort of to look to how -- what do their customers and the government there value and how do we in some sense adapt the business models that allow us to succeed there. I think intellectual property needs to be protected. I think it's China's own interest to given that they now are big intellectual property creators themselves to help ensure that intellectual property like software is protected and that's something that we have a good dialogue with the Chinese government. And I think the voices coming out of Washington are all good which is we want fair trade between countries. I believe that the next 10 years, 20 years, 30 years whatever your time frame is is going to be defined by how the United States and China not only create an equilibrium between themselves but also for the rest of the world.

BARTIROMO: But, you know, China won't even admit that they're stealing our I.P. So how do you change that behavior? Is there any way to stop that?

NADELLA: Yes. I mean, absolutely. I mean, first of all, for example as we move to the cloud, you see a shift in how people acquire intellectual property and that by itself I think is very helpful but overall, I think every country that's going through a massive transformation internally and socially and economically, I am of the belief that when you get to a certain level of GDP and GDP growth, comes with it responsibility for protecting things like intellectual property.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean, most people understand the issues around China because of that intellectual property theft but the aluminum and steel tariffs are something different. Are you expecting an impact as a result of these tariffs?

NADELLA: You know, for us, we don't see anything today in our outlook. The overall I think, this entire world order so to speak that we've seen is based on a predictable model of how goods are produced and distributed and how well you add work. And I'm hoping that we'll come back. I think the President has said that what he wants is fair deals, and so I hope that as we negotiate them that we come back to a stable environment.

BARTIROMO: Satya, obviously privacy has become the issue within the text base and in Silicon Valley particularly after the Cambridge Analytica scandal over at Facebook. A lot of people are expecting a heavier hand as it relates to technology. Are you expecting a new round of rules or regulations coming out of Washington and how will you adapt?

NADELLA: You know, privacy in my opinion is now become a human right and that's how I think of it when it comes to our products and services. And the customers and consumers everywhere are going to demand it and expect it in our products. That's why we were very, you know, aggressive and in terms of responding to GDPR, in terms of implementation and we don't even think of GDP as just a one point in time regulation. We'll have plenty more throughout the day (INAUDIBLE) the game is on Fox tonight, so we'll speak to some of the stars there (INAUDIBLE) Alex Rodriguez and others, and maybe a few surprise guests, so we'll see you throughout the day here from Nationals Park.

BARTIROMO: Awesome. Great coverage, Connell, thanks. We'll be tune in. Have fun, Connell McShane. Remember to watch the MLB All-Star game tonight at 8:00 p.m. Eastern on Fox. Coming up, we got final thoughts from this all-star panel. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Final thoughts from this all-star panel. Lindsey Bell?

BELL: I think Netflix -- we're getting a gift. This is a buying opportunity. They're spending more on content than anyone else, and I think they will bode guidance.

BARTIROMO: Wow. Even the stock is where it is. All right, Jon Hilsenrath?

HILSENRATH: 9:15 we're going to get really strong data on manufacturing sector. 10:00 a.m. we're going to have Jay Powell saying the economy is in great shape. Despite all of these angsts right now about what's happening on the trade front, the economy is in pretty good shape.

BARTIROMO: It sure is. And we're going to get a 4-1/2 percent number on GDP, you said.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: Right. That's the estimate from the Atlanta Feds for now. But the reason that there is so much optimism is because those tax cuts for corporations, they're permanent. Regardless of what the President says or does not say, that's something that companies can take to the banks.

BARTIROMO: And today, they're going to try to come up with Tax Plan 2.0 and make the individual cuts permanent.

MCDOWELL: Right. And maybe turn the attention to the economy and away from what happened in Helsinki.

HILSENRATH: I'm waiting for them to do something about the deficit. It's nice to have those tax-cuts but we've got very good --

(CROSSTALK)

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: Good luck.

BARTIROMO: Yes, good point. Thanks, everybody. Great show. Right to Varney we go. That'll do it for us. Have a great day, everybody. Here's Stuart. Stu?

VARNEY: Here I am, and good morning, Maria, and good morning, everyone.

END

urn:contentItem:5STW-1DR1-JB20-G0KV-00000-00Wal-Mart, Microsoft Take Aim At Amazon With Cloud Tech; Microsoft CEO Calls For A.I. Regulation Of Facial Recognition Technology2018-07-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:41ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTLindsey Bell, Ian BremmerNEWSDomestic071703cb.231Wal-Mart, Microsoft Take Aim At Amazon With Cloud Tech; Microsoft CEO Calls For A.I. Regulation Of Facial Recognition TechnologyMaria Bartiromo, Jon Hilsenrath, Nicole Petallides, Dagen McDowell, Stuart Varney, Connell McShane, Deidre Bolton, Kristina Partsinevelos

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good Tuesday morning. Welcome back, everybody. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Tuesday, July 17th. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. Taking on Amazon, Wal-Mart and Microsoft team up on a new cloud deal. Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella telling me in an exclusive interview why the partnership is crucial.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SATYA NADELLA, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, MICROSOFT: Everything that we think about, every places being digitized whether it's a retail outlet or a hospital, a stadium, your home or your workplace is increasingly comPuting, it's getting embedded in the real world. And in the case of Wal-Mart is a good example because if you think about Wal-Mart they have an amazing need today when it comes to anything around off-line commerce but they're increasing the momentum online.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: More of my exclusive interview with Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella straight ahead. Earnings in focus this morning on Wall Street. Three Dow components reporting their second quarter ahead of the opening bell. Johnson & Johnson, Goldman Sachs, and UnitedHealth are all out. Goldman Sachs President David Solomon will become CEO on October 1 according to the New York Times. The handoff to David Solomon was expected and now we know the date October 1 a change in leadership at Goldman Sachs. Markets this morning look like this, futures edging lower. The Dow Industrials now at the low of the morning here down about 30 points. The S&P 500 down three and the NASDAQ down 3-/2. This after the markets finished the day mixed yesterday. Take a look, Dow Industrials picked up 45 points but the S&P and the NASDAQ fractionally lower on the session.

And in Europe this morning, markets are lower across the board. The FT-100 down nine points, the CAC quarante down 25, that's a half of a percent. And the DAX Index in Germany down a quarter of a percent. In Asia overnight, mixed performances, take a look the best performer was Japan, Nikkei Average up one-half of one percent. Amazon prime day will under way but it got off to a rock start outages prevented customers from making purchases yesterday. The fallout for the retail giant on the biggest sales day of the year.

And it was a wild night at the Home Run Derby, Bryce Harper pulling off a last second win at his home stadium. We have all the highlights. All those stories coming up this Tuesday morning and joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, The Wall Street Journal global economics editor, Jon Hilsenrath and CFRA investment strategist, Lindsey Bell. Great show so far guys.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: Good to be here. And earnings are doing very, very well, 19.6 percent on the S&P 500. 90 percent of companies beating the bottom line.

BARTIROMO: And revenue?

BELL: And revenue, 87 percent finish top line.

BARTIROMO: Just for the second quarter.

BELL: Nine percent revenue.

JON HILSENRATH, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CONTRIBUTOR: The estimates are for earnings of 26 or 27 percent, isn't it?

BARTIROMO: Not second quarter.

(CROSSTALK)

BELL: the numbers --

(CROSSTALK)

HILSENRATH: -- getting better as the new numbers comes.

BARTIROMO: So you think the earnings period gets even better for the second quarter?

HILSENRATH: Could be.

BARTIROMO: All right. We're going to keep watching that. We want to look at Microsoft which is of course is reporting earnings later this week. It is teaming up with Wal-Mart to take on Amazon. The retail giant looking to accelerate its digital transformation with the help of Microsoft's cloud technology. I spoke exclusively with Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella for his take on the partnership, privacy concerns facing technology today and where Microsoft can continue to grow.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

NADELLA: The core mission of our company really comes through in the momentum we have. If you think about it, we sort of describe our mission as empowering every person in every organization on the planet to achieve more. In our words, our success, whatever we have of it is dependent on our costumers succeeding in an increasingly digital world. That's what you see what's on the examples like Wal-Mart who's patterned deeply with us and others.

BARTIROMO: It's interesting because this announcement with Wal-Mart, a strategic partnership, it's a digital transformation for Wal-Mart but you're calling this a 4-1/2 trillion opportunity. This transformation to digital.

NADELLA: Yes, it's actually frustration. If we think about it for all the success of digital technology companies on a percentage basis of the GDP, the worldwide GDP, I think the text banned is just around five percent. It is expected to go to 10 percent next 10 years. But the real question is, what is the opportunity for the other 95 percent of GDP or the 90 percent of the GDP. How are they going to use the digital technology, doing some sense digital companies in their own right. Whether it's any retailer like Wal-Mart or any health company, 81 across all industries is going to look to digital technology to bring about the next level of experience innovation or cost savings.

BARTIROMO: And for Wal-Mart, this is a critical transition as it battles with Amazon who of course, has been incredibly aggressive in that space. Tell me about I.T. budgets today. Are you seeing that increase in technology spending? I know that there was a pretty good lift when the tax plan first came out in anticipation of the tax cut plan but there was worries that things have slowed down. Are you still seeing I.T. budgets increase and are you seeing the kind of spend that you would expect?

NADELLA: No, I mean, on a long-term basis, if I had to sort of look at it, tax spend or digital spend is absolutely going to increase just because everything that we think about every place is being digitized whether it's a retail outlet or a hospital, a stadium, your home or your workplace is increasing comPuting, it's getting embedded in the real world. Every experience is being driven by more and more A.I. capability. So that's what's going to keep driving more tax spend. It's going to essentially -- I think over the world's operating expense as well as cogs are being digitized. And in the case of Wal-Mart is a good example because if you think about Wal-Mart, they're having amazing lead today when it comes to anything around off-line commerce. But they're increasing their momentum online.

BARTIROMO: Is the priority for companies today whether big or small, because let's not forget Microsoft is really the priority for smaller and midcap companies as well in addition to the G.E.s and the Wal-Marts of the world. But is the spend priority in terms of security right now or is it cloud? Where would you see the priority is in terms of corporate spending?

NADELLA: I would say the number one priority is around productivity and digital transformation.

BARTIROMO: Was it the tax cut plan that encouraged you to take some money back to the U.S.?

NADELLA: I mean, I think we've had a pretty balanced approach. First and foremost we are being very aggressive spenders in R&D dollars and operating expenses right here in the United States. And if you look at what we do, we do (INAUDIBLE) $30 plus billion spend every year, and majority 85 percent of it is right here in the United States. And so we continue to bet on the organic growth and innovation but we are complementing that, whether it's with LinkedIn or pending acquisition or GitHub or what you did earlier with Minecraft. We are looking for assets that can complement what we do well and as well as dividends and buybacks. So, we think having that approach which is some in some sense more stable across all various different forms and spend patterns in business cycles is important. But at at the end of the day what matters to us is continue to drive the innovation and growth in this company.

BARTIROMO: You have been in China for a long time and I have a stat here, someone said to me that there was expectation that 97 percent of companies in China use Microsoft Windows and more than 90 percent do not pay for it. You have been dealing with piracy this for a long time. What can you tell us about it?

NADELLA: I mean, I think one of the fundamental things that been -- have been our approach in China is to be able sort of to look to how -- what do their customers and the government there value and how do we in some sense adapt the business models that allow us to succeed there. I think intellectual property needs to be protected. I think it's China's own interest to given that they now are big intellectual property creators themselves to help ensure that intellectual property like software is protected and that's something that we have a good dialogue with the Chinese government. And I think the voices coming out of Washington are all good which is we want fair trade between countries. I believe that the next 10 years, 20 years, 30 years whatever your time frame is is going to be defined by how the United States and China not only create an equilibrium between themselves but also for the rest of the world.

BARTIROMO: But, you know, China won't even admit that they're stealing our I.P. So how do you change that behavior? Is there any way to stop that?

NADELLA: Yes. I mean, absolutely. I mean, first of all, for example as we move to the cloud, you see a shift in how people acquire intellectual property and that by itself I think is very helpful but overall, I think every country that's going through a massive transformation internally and socially and economically, I am of the belief that when you get to a certain level of GDP and GDP growth, comes with it responsibility for protecting things like intellectual property.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean, most people understand the issues around China because of that intellectual property theft but the aluminum and steel tariffs are something different. Are you expecting an impact as a result of these tariffs?

NADELLA: You know, for us, we don't see anything today in our outlook. The overall I think, this entire world order so to speak that we've seen is based on a predictable model of how goods are produced and distributed and how well you add work. And I'm hoping that we'll come back. I think the President has said that what he wants is fair deals, and so I hope that as we negotiate them that we come back to a stable environment.

BARTIROMO: Satya, obviously privacy has become the issue within the text base and in Silicon Valley particularly after the Cambridge Analytica scandal over at Facebook. A lot of people are expecting a heavier hand as it relates to technology. Are you expecting a new round of rules or regulations coming out of Washington and how will you adapt?

NADELLA: You know, privacy in my opinion is now become a human right and that's how I think of it when it comes to our products and services. And the customers and consumers everywhere are going to demand it and expect it in our products. That's why we were very, you know, aggressive and in terms of responding to GDPR, in terms of implementation and we don't even think of GDP as just a one point in time regulation. It requires an ongoing commitment to compliance around privacy. And I think that -- I fully expect that more countries and more geographies including the United States are going to take a, you know, a lead from what the Europeans have done.

BARTIROMO: Let's talk about your contract with the U.S. Immigration and Customs enforcements. Obviously a lot of noise around this, given the separation of families. I know your contract with ICE involves the legacy mail, e-mail, calendar, messenger and documents. Is there a potential for using the facial recognition as well?

NADELLA: We have been very clear, in fact, a multiple years ago is when I wrote about RAI principals and how we are going to make sure that A.I. technology that we build and how it's used is always going to be driven by set of enduring principles. Now, one of the things that we recognize is with A.I. technology with all the benefits comes from unintended uses. Like bias or facial recognition. And so therefore, we are very clear that we will not participate in any project that is going to be against, you know, fundamental human rights. And in this case, what we are doing with ICE is to support them in the core infrastructure around e-mail but we are not at all involved in any of the facial recognition technology and their use cases. But more importantly we think that its' not just about a single company having principal approach which we do but it's also having a set of rules and regulations especially in a democracy like ours. Instead of us trying to govern the government, I think the legislative process should govern the companies and their technologies and the uses. That's what the blog, the Brad Smith wrote last week really outlines and we in fact welcome any regulation and any expert comedy that the legislative process creates. And then the rules and policies that come out of it.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I was looking at Brad Smith's post and the truth is is we are in sort of an uncertain term -- time. When you look at A.I. and machine learning, there's a balance to walk here that these things are making our lives so much easier but at the same time people worried that it is in fact infringing on our privacy. There is that balance that Microsoft, the entire tech sector has to -- has to walk.

BARTIROMO: That's absolutely correct. When it will comes to things like security or cybersecurity, privacy in A.I., I think in all of these cases two things need to happen. One is companies like us at Microsoft, we need to take responsibility and protect privacy as a human right, ensure things like we are doing with cybersecurity, like the Tech Accord. I think cover as like the Geneva Convention in the cybersecurity world. As well as have ethical principles that drive the development and the use of A.I. But on top of it, I think the governments around the world also have their role.

BARTIROMO: As Congress plans to come up with a new solution here going into midterm elections, what kind of a legal immigration system would you like to see?

NADELLA: You know, first of all, Maria, I am a product of I think two amazingly unique things, American, one is American technology that reached me where I was growing up and letting me dream the dream and American immigration policy that then allowed me to come here, get an education and live that dream. So I'll always come from that personal experience to advocate for and enlighten immigration policy that allows the -- for the best and the brightest to come to the United States, participate in our economy, pay taxes, create innovations that are going to make us more competitive globally.

BARTIROMO: Are you finding employees that you need to put in the jobs that you have open? Recently we learned that there are more job openings than actually people to fill those jobs.

NADELLA: I mean, I think we are seeing definitely growth is much faster and so therefore we have always have insatiable need for new talent and better talent. Be definitely can employ more people but at the same time I think this fantastic people in the right here in the schools in the United States as well as in the industry. So I think that yes, immigration, policy reform is required but I would not sort of use that as only thing that is required in order for us to continue to grow in the united states.

BARTIROMO: Well, final question here, Satya. Obviously you're doing a lot, right? How does it feel sitting on the doorstep of a $1-trillion market value from Microsoft right now?

NADELLA: For us I think, Maria, is going to come down to what I said which is how can we ensure that we stay focused on building technologies that are relevant in helping our customers.

BARTIROMO: Satya, it's great to see you today. Thanks so much. And congratulations to you.

NADELLA: Thank you so much, Maria.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: We'll be right back. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. As we told you earlier, Goldman Sachs announced that David Solomon will take over for Lloyd Blankfein as CEO beginning October 1. Nicole Petallides is on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange with details looking at the stock. Nicole, good morning.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria. So it's finally official, I mean, David Solomon has been speculated to be the succession to Lloyd Blankfein in this top role particularly after the Goldman co-President Harvey Schwartz was out. And so now, he is going to take the helm on October 1st. He will be the third Goldman CEO since it went public in 1999. Of course, Hank Paulson who have gone on to be treasury secretary under George W. Bush, then Lloyd Blankfein and now David Soloman. Veteran investment banker will be taking over on October 1st. Now we're also -- by the way, he's also a D.J., that was another underlying story on his spare time which I thought was really cute in Miami, New York, and Bahamas. Let's take a look also at the numbers. You can see that the stock is down about a quarter of a percent. They did beat on profit and revenue. urn:contentItem:5SV2-2T91-JBHT-D32Y-00000-00Wal-Mart, Microsoft Take Aim At Amazon With Cloud Tech; Microsoft CEO Calls For A.I. Regulation Of Facial Recognition Technology2018-07-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:41ZLexisNexisWal-Mart, Microsoft Take Aim At Amazon With Cloud Tech; Microsoft CEO Calls For A.I. Regulation Of Facial Recognition TechnologyLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good Tuesday morning. Welcome back, everybody. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Tuesday, July 17th. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. Taking on Amazon, Wal-Mart and Microsoft team up on a new cloud deal. Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella telling me in an exclusive interview why the partnership is crucial.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SATYA NADELLA, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, MICROSOFT: Everything that we think about, every places being digitized whether it's a retail outlet or a hospital, a stadium, your home or your workplace is increasingly comPuting, it's getting embedded in the real world. And in the case of Wal-Mart is a good example because if you think about Wal-Mart they have an amazing need today when it comes to anything around off-line commerce but they're increasing the momentum online.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: More of my exclusive interview with Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella straight ahead. Earnings in focus this morning on Wall Street. Three Dow components reporting their second quarter ahead of the opening bell. Johnson & Johnson, Goldman Sachs, and UnitedHealth are all out. Goldman Sachs President David Solomon will become CEO on October 1 according to the New York Times. The handoff to David Solomon was expected and now we know the date October 1 a change in leadership at Goldman Sachs. Markets this morning look like this, futures edging lower. The Dow Industrials now at the low of the morning here down about 30 points. The S&P 500 down three and the NASDAQ down 3-/2. This after the markets finished the day mixed yesterday. Take a look, Dow Industrials picked up 45 points but the S&P and the NASDAQ fractionally lower on the session.

And in Europe this morning, markets are lower across the board. The FT-100 down nine points, the CAC quarante down 25, that's a half of a percent. And the DAX Index in Germany down a quarter of a percent. In Asia overnight, mixed performances, take a look the best performer was Japan, Nikkei Average up one-half of one percent. Amazon prime day will under way but it got off to a rock start outages prevented customers from making purchases yesterday. The fallout for the retail giant on the biggest sales day of the year.

And it was a wild night at the Home Run Derby, Bryce Harper pulling off a last second win at his home stadium. We have all the highlights. All those stories coming up this Tuesday morning and joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, The Wall Street Journal global economics editor, Jon Hilsenrath and CFRA investment strategist, Lindsey Bell. Great show so far guys.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: Good to be here. And earnings are doing very, very well, 19.6 percent on the S&P 500. 90 percent of companies beating the bottom line.

BARTIROMO: And revenue?

BELL: And revenue, 87 percent finish top line.

BARTIROMO: Just for the second quarter.

BELL: Nine percent revenue.

JON HILSENRATH, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CONTRIBUTOR: The estimates are for earnings of 26 or 27 percent, isn't it?

BARTIROMO: Not second quarter.

(CROSSTALK)

BELL: the numbers --

(CROSSTALK)

HILSENRATH: -- getting better as the new numbers comes.

BARTIROMO: So you think the earnings period gets even better for the second quarter?

HILSENRATH: Could be.

BARTIROMO: All right. We're going to keep watching that. We want to look at Microsoft which is of course is reporting earnings later this week. It is teaming up with Wal-Mart to take on Amazon. The retail giant looking to accelerate its digital transformation with the help of Microsoft's cloud technology. I spoke exclusively with Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella for his take on the partnership, privacy concerns facing technology today and where Microsoft can continue to grow.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

NADELLA: The core mission of our company really comes through in the momentum we have. If you think about it, we sort of describe our mission as empowering every person in every organization on the planet to achieve more. In our words, our success, whatever we have of it is dependent on our costumers succeeding in an increasingly digital world. That's what you see what's on the examples like Wal-Mart who's patterned deeply with us and others.

BARTIROMO: It's interesting because this announcement with Wal-Mart, a strategic partnership, it's a digital transformation for Wal-Mart but you're calling this a 4-1/2 trillion opportunity. This transformation to digital.

NADELLA: Yes, it's actually frustration. If we think about it for all the success of digital technology companies on a percentage basis of the GDP, the worldwide GDP, I think the text banned is just around five percent. It is expected to go to 10 percent next 10 years. But the real question is, what is the opportunity for the other 95 percent of GDP or the 90 percent of the GDP. How are they going to use the digital technology, doing some sense digital companies in their own right. Whether it's any retailer like Wal-Mart or any health company, 81 across all industries is going to look to digital technology to bring about the next level of experience innovation or cost savings.

BARTIROMO: And for Wal-Mart, this is a critical transition as it battles with Amazon who of course, has been incredibly aggressive in that space. Tell me about I.T. budgets today. Are you seeing that increase in technology spending? I know that there was a pretty good lift when the tax plan first came out in anticipation of the tax cut plan but there was worries that things have slowed down. Are you still seeing I.T. budgets increase and are you seeing the kind of spend that you would expect?

NADELLA: No, I mean, on a long-term basis, if I had to sort of look at it, tax spend or digital spend is absolutely going to increase just because everything that we think about every place is being digitized whether it's a retail outlet or a hospital, a stadium, your home or your workplace is increasing comPuting, it's getting embedded in the real world. Every experience is being driven by more and more A.I. capability. So that's what's going to keep driving more tax spend. It's going to essentially -- I think over the world's operating expense as well as cogs are being digitized. And in the case of Wal-Mart is a good example because if you think about Wal-Mart, they're having amazing lead today when it comes to anything around off-line commerce. But they're increasing their momentum online.

BARTIROMO: Is the priority for companies today whether big or small, because let's not forget Microsoft is really the priority for smaller and midcap companies as well in addition to the G.E.s and the Wal-Marts of the world. But is the spend priority in terms of security right now or is it cloud? Where would you see the priority is in terms of corporate spending?

NADELLA: I would say the number one priority is around productivity and digital transformation.

BARTIROMO: Was it the tax cut plan that encouraged you to take some money back to the U.S.?

NADELLA: I mean, I think we've had a pretty balanced approach. First and foremost we are being very aggressive spenders in R&D dollars and operating expenses right here in the United States. And if you look at what we do, we do (INAUDIBLE) $30 plus billion spend every year, and majority 85 percent of it is right here in the United States. And so we continue to bet on the organic growth and innovation but we are complementing that, whether it's with LinkedIn or pending acquisition or GitHub or what you did earlier with Minecraft. We are looking for assets that can complement what we do well and as well as dividends and buybacks. So, we think having that approach which is some in some sense more stable across all various different forms and spend patterns in business cycles is important. But at at the end of the day what matters to us is continue to drive the innovation and growth in this company.

BARTIROMO: You have been in China for a long time and I have a stat here, someone said to me that there was expectation that 97 percent of companies in China use Microsoft Windows and more than 90 percent do not pay for it. You have been dealing with piracy this for a long time. What can you tell us about it?

NADELLA: I mean, I think one of the fundamental things that been -- have been our approach in China is to be able sort of to look to how -- what do their customers and the government there value and how do we in some sense adapt the business models that allow us to succeed there. I think intellectual property needs to be protected. I think it's China's own interest to given that they now are big intellectual property creators themselves to help ensure that intellectual property like software is protected and that's something that we have a good dialogue with the Chinese government. And I think the voices coming out of Washington are all good which is we want fair trade between countries. I believe that the next 10 years, 20 years, 30 years whatever your time frame is is going to be defined by how the United States and China not only create an equilibrium between themselves but also for the rest of the world.

BARTIROMO: But, you know, China won't even admit that they're stealing our I.P. So how do you change that behavior? Is there any way to stop that?

NADELLA: Yes. I mean, absolutely. I mean, first of all, for example as we move to the cloud, you see a shift in how people acquire intellectual property and that by itself I think is very helpful but overall, I think every country that's going through a massive transformation internally and socially and economically, I am of the belief that when you get to a certain level of GDP and GDP growth, comes with it responsibility for protecting things like intellectual property.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean, most people understand the issues around China because of that intellectual property theft but the aluminum and steel tariffs are something different. Are you expecting an impact as a result of these tariffs?

NADELLA: You know, for us, we don't see anything today in our outlook. The overall I think, this entire world order so to speak that we've seen is based on a predictable model of how goods are produced and distributed and how well you add work. And I'm hoping that we'll come back. I think the President has said that what he wants is fair deals, and so I hope that as we negotiate them that we come back to a stable environment.

BARTIROMO: Satya, obviously privacy has become the issue within the text base and in Silicon Valley particularly after the Cambridge Analytica scandal over at Facebook. A lot of people are expecting a heavier hand as it relates to technology. Are you expecting a new round of rules or regulations coming out of Washington and how will you adapt?

NADELLA: You know, privacy in my opinion is now become a human right and that's how I think of it when it comes to our products and services. And the customers and consumers everywhere are going to demand it and expect it in our products. That's why we were very, you know, aggressive and in terms of responding to GDPR, in terms of implementation and we don't even think of GDP as just a one point in time regulation. It requires an ongoing commitment to compliance around privacy. And I think that -- I fully expect that more countries and more geographies including the United States are going to take a, you know, a lead from what the Europeans have done.

BARTIROMO: Let's talk about your contract with the U.S. Immigration and Customs enforcements. Obviously a lot of noise around this, given the separation of families. I know your contract with ICE involves the legacy mail, e-mail, calendar, messenger and documents. Is there a potential for using the facial recognition as well?

NADELLA: We have been very clear, in fact, a multiple years ago is when I wrote about RAI principals and how we are going to make sure that A.I. technology that we build and how it's used is always going to be driven by set of enduring principles. Now, one of the things that we recognize is with A.I. technology with all the benefits comes from unintended uses. Like bias or facial recognition. And so therefore, we are very clear that we will not participate in any project that is going to be against, you know, fundamental human rights. And in this case, what we are doing with ICE is to support them in the core infrastructure around e-mail but we are not at all involved in any of the facial recognition technology and their use cases. But more importantly we think that its' not just about a single company having principal approach which we do but it's also having a set of rules and regulations especially in a democracy like ours. Instead of us trying to govern the government, I think the legislative process should govern the companies and their technologies and the uses. That's what the blog, the Brad Smith wrote last week really outlines and we in fact welcome any regulation and any expert comedy that the legislative process creates. And then the rules and policies that come out of it.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I was looking at Brad Smith's post and the truth is is we are in sort of an uncertain term -- time. When you look at A.I. and machine learning, there's a balance to walk here that these things are making our lives so much easier but at the same time people worried that it is in fact infringing on our privacy. There is that balance that Microsoft, the entire tech sector has to -- has to walk.

BARTIROMO: That's absolutely correct. When it will comes to things like security or cybersecurity, privacy in A.I., I think in all of these cases two things need to happen. One is companies like us at Microsoft, we need to take responsibility and protect privacy as a human right, ensure things like we are doing with cybersecurity, like the Tech Accord. I think cover as like the Geneva Convention in the cybersecurity world. As well as have ethical principles that drive the development and the use of A.I. But on top of it, I think the governments around the world also have their role.

BARTIROMO: As Congress plans to come up with a new solution here going into midterm elections, what kind of a legal immigration system would you like to see?

NADELLA: You know, first of all, Maria, I am a product of I think two amazingly unique things, American, one is American technology that reached me where I was growing up and letting me dream the dream and American immigration policy that then allowed me to come here, get an education and live that dream. So I'll always come from that personal experience to advocate for and enlighten immigration policy that allows the -- for the best and the brightest to come to the United States, participate in our economy, pay taxes, create innovations that are going to make us more competitive globally.

BARTIROMO: Are you finding employees that you need to put in the jobs that you have open? Recently we learned that there are more job openings than actually people to fill those jobs.

NADELLA: I mean, I think we are seeing definitely growth is much faster and so therefore we have always have insatiable need for new talent and better talent. Be definitely can employ more people but at the same time I think this fantastic people in the right here in the schools in the United States as well as in the industry. So I think that yes, immigration, policy reform is required but I would not sort of use that as only thing that is required in order for us to continue to grow in the united states.

BARTIROMO: Well, final question here, Satya. Obviously you're doing a lot, right? How does it feel sitting on the doorstep of a $1-trillion market value from Microsoft right now?

NADELLA: For us I think, Maria, is going to come down to what I said which is how can we ensure that we stay focused on building technologies that are relevant in helping our customers.

BARTIROMO: Satya, it's great to see you today. Thanks so much. And congratulations to you.

NADELLA: Thank you so much, Maria.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: We'll be right back. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. As we told you earlier, Goldman Sachs announced that David Solomon will take over for Lloyd Blankfein as CEO beginning October 1. Nicole Petallides is on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange with details looking at the stock. Nicole, good morning.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria. So it's finally official, I mean, David Solomon has been speculated to be the succession to Lloyd Blankfein in this top role particularly after the Goldman co-President Harvey Schwartz was out. And so now, he is going to take the helm on October 1st. He will be the third Goldman CEO since it went public in 1999. Of course, Hank Paulson who have gone on to be treasury secretary under George W. Bush, then Lloyd Blankfein and now David Soloman. Veteran investment banker will be taking over on October 1st. Now we're also -- by the way, he's also a D.J., that was another underlying story on his spare time which I thought was really cute in Miami, New York, and Bahamas. Let's take a look also at the numbers. You can see that the stock is down about a quarter of a percent. They did beat on profit and revenue. Revenue was listed by fixed income where they're not able to make it as the trading revenue clients are just a little spooked by the sharp price moves and so the strength certainly with investment banking and that was a winner. Johnson & Johnson, that is up right now after a beat strong dollar did hurt, defending itself in the talc issues. And last but not least, you are seeing UnitedHealth to the downside. The premiums missed and also medical loss ratio missed estimates but they did raise a forecast and did have some good numbers but a couple of misses weighing on the stock. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right. Stock down almost two percent UnitedHealth. Thank you, Nicole. Coming up. Amazon prime day starts with a glitch. Problems with the retail giant's Web site. Shoppers searching for deals later this hour. Then there is, Bryce Harper making an epic comeback. The highlights from last night's Home Run Derby coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Trade tensions escalating in the United States. Filing complaints against trading partners including Canada, China, the European Union. This after lawsuits were filed against the U.S. through the World Trade Organization over the steel and aluminum tariffs. Joining us right now is Ian Bremmer, President of the Eurasia Group and GZERO Media. Ian, great to see you this morning.

IAN BREMMER, PRESIDENT, EURASIA GROUP: Hi, Maia. Good morning to you.

BARTIROMO: What progress is being made on the trade front? Where are you in this trade dispute whether if it would with China or our allies on aluminum and steel?

BREMMER: So far, as you say, we have a dueling suits that have been put in place with the World Trade Organization. The the good news is that for those that were saying that there is draft, you know, sort of order going around from -- in the White House saying that Trump wants to withdraw the United States from the WTO, that was never feasible in terms of Congress. And it was never something that the Trump administration in any had a consensus in moving towards. They are using the WTO as the allies are, as China is and if this ends up getting resolved by the established multilateral trade organization over years, that's a much better place to be than unfettered escalation on trade.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Ian, it's Dagen McDowell. The commerce department under President Trump is studying this potential tariff on automobile imports into the United States, maybe 20 percent, maybe higher. They're looking at it right now.
