Regulation Of Facial Recognition Technology2018-07-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:41ZLexisNexisWal-Mart, Microsoft Take Aim At Amazon With Cloud Tech; Microsoft CEO Calls For A.I. Regulation Of Facial Recognition TechnologyLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good Tuesday morning. Welcome back, everybody. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Tuesday, July 17th. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. Taking on Amazon, Wal-Mart and Microsoft team up on a new cloud deal. Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella telling me in an exclusive interview why the partnership is crucial.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SATYA NADELLA, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, MICROSOFT: Everything that we think about, every places being digitized whether it's a retail outlet or a hospital, a stadium, your home or your workplace is increasingly comPuting, it's getting embedded in the real world. And in the case of Wal-Mart is a good example because if you think about Wal-Mart they have an amazing need today when it comes to anything around off-line commerce but they're increasing the momentum online.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: More of my exclusive interview with Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella straight ahead. Earnings in focus this morning on Wall Street. Three Dow components reporting their second quarter ahead of the opening bell. Johnson & Johnson, Goldman Sachs, and UnitedHealth are all out. Goldman Sachs President David Solomon will become CEO on October 1 according to the New York Times. The handoff to David Solomon was expected and now we know the date October 1 a change in leadership at Goldman Sachs. Markets this morning look like this, futures edging lower. The Dow Industrials now at the low of the morning here down about 30 points. The S&P 500 down three and the NASDAQ down 3-/2. This after the markets finished the day mixed yesterday. Take a look, Dow Industrials picked up 45 points but the S&P and the NASDAQ fractionally lower on the session.

And in Europe this morning, markets are lower across the board. The FT-100 down nine points, the CAC quarante down 25, that's a half of a percent. And the DAX Index in Germany down a quarter of a percent. In Asia overnight, mixed performances, take a look the best performer was Japan, Nikkei Average up one-half of one percent. Amazon prime day will under way but it got off to a rock start outages prevented customers from making purchases yesterday. The fallout for the retail giant on the biggest sales day of the year.

And it was a wild night at the Home Run Derby, Bryce Harper pulling off a last second win at his home stadium. We have all the highlights. All those stories coming up this Tuesday morning and joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, The Wall Street Journal global economics editor, Jon Hilsenrath and CFRA investment strategist, Lindsey Bell. Great show so far guys.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: Good to be here. And earnings are doing very, very well, 19.6 percent on the S&P 500. 90 percent of companies beating the bottom line.

BARTIROMO: And revenue?

BELL: And revenue, 87 percent finish top line.

BARTIROMO: Just for the second quarter.

BELL: Nine percent revenue.

JON HILSENRATH, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CONTRIBUTOR: The estimates are for earnings of 26 or 27 percent, isn't it?

BARTIROMO: Not second quarter.

(CROSSTALK)

BELL: the numbers --

(CROSSTALK)

HILSENRATH: -- getting better as the new numbers comes.

BARTIROMO: So you think the earnings period gets even better for the second quarter?

HILSENRATH: Could be.

BARTIROMO: All right. We're going to keep watching that. We want to look at Microsoft which is of course is reporting earnings later this week. It is teaming up with Wal-Mart to take on Amazon. The retail giant looking to accelerate its digital transformation with the help of Microsoft's cloud technology. I spoke exclusively with Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella for his take on the partnership, privacy concerns facing technology today and where Microsoft can continue to grow.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

NADELLA: The core mission of our company really comes through in the momentum we have. If you think about it, we sort of describe our mission as empowering every person in every organization on the planet to achieve more. In our words, our success, whatever we have of it is dependent on our costumers succeeding in an increasingly digital world. That's what you see what's on the examples like Wal-Mart who's patterned deeply with us and others.

BARTIROMO: It's interesting because this announcement with Wal-Mart, a strategic partnership, it's a digital transformation for Wal-Mart but you're calling this a 4-1/2 trillion opportunity. This transformation to digital.

NADELLA: Yes, it's actually frustration. If we think about it for all the success of digital technology companies on a percentage basis of the GDP, the worldwide GDP, I think the text banned is just around five percent. It is expected to go to 10 percent next 10 years. But the real question is, what is the opportunity for the other 95 percent of GDP or the 90 percent of the GDP. How are they going to use the digital technology, doing some sense digital companies in their own right. Whether it's any retailer like Wal-Mart or any health company, 81 across all industries is going to look to digital technology to bring about the next level of experience innovation or cost savings.

BARTIROMO: And for Wal-Mart, this is a critical transition as it battles with Amazon who of course, has been incredibly aggressive in that space. Tell me about I.T. budgets today. Are you seeing that increase in technology spending? I know that there was a pretty good lift when the tax plan first came out in anticipation of the tax cut plan but there was worries that things have slowed down. Are you still seeing I.T. budgets increase and are you seeing the kind of spend that you would expect?

NADELLA: No, I mean, on a long-term basis, if I had to sort of look at it, tax spend or digital spend is absolutely going to increase just because everything that we think about every place is being digitized whether it's a retail outlet or a hospital, a stadium, your home or your workplace is increasing comPuting, it's getting embedded in the real world. Every experience is being driven by more and more A.I. capability. So that's what's going to keep driving more tax spend. It's going to essentially -- I think over the world's operating expense as well as cogs are being digitized. And in the case of Wal-Mart is a good example because if you think about Wal-Mart, they're having amazing lead today when it comes to anything around off-line commerce. But they're increasing their momentum online.

BARTIROMO: Is the priority for companies today whether big or small, because let's not forget Microsoft is really the priority for smaller and midcap companies as well in addition to the G.E.s and the Wal-Marts of the world. But is the spend priority in terms of security right now or is it cloud? Where would you see the priority is in terms of corporate spending?

NADELLA: I would say the number one priority is around productivity and digital transformation.

BARTIROMO: Was it the tax cut plan that encouraged you to take some money back to the U.S.?

NADELLA: I mean, I think we've had a pretty balanced approach. First and foremost we are being very aggressive spenders in R&D dollars and operating expenses right here in the United States. And if you look at what we do, we do (INAUDIBLE) $30 plus billion spend every year, and majority 85 percent of it is right here in the United States. And so we continue to bet on the organic growth and innovation but we are complementing that, whether it's with LinkedIn or pending acquisition or GitHub or what you did earlier with Minecraft. We are looking for assets that can complement what we do well and as well as dividends and buybacks. So, we think having that approach which is some in some sense more stable across all various different forms and spend patterns in business cycles is important. But at at the end of the day what matters to us is continue to drive the innovation and growth in this company.

BARTIROMO: You have been in China for a long time and I have a stat here, someone said to me that there was expectation that 97 percent of companies in China use Microsoft Windows and more than 90 percent do not pay for it. You have been dealing with piracy this for a long time. What can you tell us about it?

NADELLA: I mean, I think one of the fundamental things that been -- have been our approach in China is to be able sort of to look to how -- what do their customers and the government there value and how do we in some sense adapt the business models that allow us to succeed there. I think intellectual property needs to be protected. I think it's China's own interest to given that they now are big intellectual property creators themselves to help ensure that intellectual property like software is protected and that's something that we have a good dialogue with the Chinese government. And I think the voices coming out of Washington are all good which is we want fair trade between countries. I believe that the next 10 years, 20 years, 30 years whatever your time frame is is going to be defined by how the United States and China not only create an equilibrium between themselves but also for the rest of the world.

BARTIROMO: But, you know, China won't even admit that they're stealing our I.P. So how do you change that behavior? Is there any way to stop that?

NADELLA: Yes. I mean, absolutely. I mean, first of all, for example as we move to the cloud, you see a shift in how people acquire intellectual property and that by itself I think is very helpful but overall, I think every country that's going through a massive transformation internally and socially and economically, I am of the belief that when you get to a certain level of GDP and GDP growth, comes with it responsibility for protecting things like intellectual property.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean, most people understand the issues around China because of that intellectual property theft but the aluminum and steel tariffs are something different. Are you expecting an impact as a result of these tariffs?

NADELLA: You know, for us, we don't see anything today in our outlook. The overall I think, this entire world order so to speak that we've seen is based on a predictable model of how goods are produced and distributed and how well you add work. And I'm hoping that we'll come back. I think the President has said that what he wants is fair deals, and so I hope that as we negotiate them that we come back to a stable environment.

BARTIROMO: Satya, obviously privacy has become the issue within the text base and in Silicon Valley particularly after the Cambridge Analytica scandal over at Facebook. A lot of people are expecting a heavier hand as it relates to technology. Are you expecting a new round of rules or regulations coming out of Washington and how will you adapt?

NADELLA: You know, privacy in my opinion is now become a human right and that's how I think of it when it comes to our products and services. And the customers and consumers everywhere are going to demand it and expect it in our products. That's why we were very, you know, aggressive and in terms of responding to GDPR, in terms of implementation and we don't even think of GDP as just a one point in time regulation. It requires an ongoing commitment to compliance around privacy. And I think that -- I fully expect that more countries and more geographies including the United States are going to take a, you know, a lead from what the Europeans have done.

BARTIROMO: Let's talk about your contract with the U.S. Immigration and Customs enforcements. Obviously a lot of noise around this, given the separation of families. I know your contract with ICE involves the legacy mail, e-mail, calendar, messenger and documents. Is there a potential for using the facial recognition as well?

NADELLA: We have been very clear, in fact, a multiple years ago is when I wrote about RAI principals and how we are going to make sure that A.I. technology that we build and how it's used is always going to be driven by set of enduring principles. Now, one of the things that we recognize is with A.I. technology with all the benefits comes from unintended uses. Like bias or facial recognition. And so therefore, we are very clear that we will not participate in any project that is going to be against, you know, fundamental human rights. And in this case, what we are doing with ICE is to support them in the core infrastructure around e-mail but we are not at all involved in any of the facial recognition technology and their use cases. But more importantly we think that its' not just about a single company having principal approach which we do but it's also having a set of rules and regulations especially in a democracy like ours. Instead of us trying to govern the government, I think the legislative process should govern the companies and their technologies and the uses. That's what the blog, the Brad Smith wrote last week really outlines and we in fact welcome any regulation and any expert comedy that the legislative process creates. And then the rules and policies that come out of it.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I was looking at Brad Smith's post and the truth is is we are in sort of an uncertain term -- time. When you look at A.I. and machine learning, there's a balance to walk here that these things are making our lives so much easier but at the same time people worried that it is in fact infringing on our privacy. There is that balance that Microsoft, the entire tech sector has to -- has to walk.

BARTIROMO: That's absolutely correct. When it will comes to things like security or cybersecurity, privacy in A.I., I think in all of these cases two things need to happen. One is companies like us at Microsoft, we need to take responsibility and protect privacy as a human right, ensure things like we are doing with cybersecurity, like the Tech Accord. I think cover as like the Geneva Convention in the cybersecurity world. As well as have ethical principles that drive the development and the use of A.I. But on top of it, I think the governments around the world also have their role.

BARTIROMO: As Congress plans to come up with a new solution here going into midterm elections, what kind of a legal immigration system would you like to see?

NADELLA: You know, first of all, Maria, I am a product of I think two amazingly unique things, American, one is American technology that reached me where I was growing up and letting me dream the dream and American immigration policy that then allowed me to come here, get an education and live that dream. So I'll always come from that personal experience to advocate for and enlighten immigration policy that allows the -- for the best and the brightest to come to the United States, participate in our economy, pay taxes, create innovations that are going to make us more competitive globally.

BARTIROMO: Are you finding employees that you need to put in the jobs that you have open? Recently we learned that there are more job openings than actually people to fill those jobs.

NADELLA: I mean, I think we are seeing definitely growth is much faster and so therefore we have always have insatiable need for new talent and better talent. Be definitely can employ more people but at the same time I think this fantastic people in the right here in the schools in the United States as well as in the industry. So I think that yes, immigration, policy reform is required but I would not sort of use that as only thing that is required in order for us to continue to grow in the united states.

BARTIROMO: Well, final question here, Satya. Obviously you're doing a lot, right? How does it feel sitting on the doorstep of a $1-trillion market value from Microsoft right now?

NADELLA: For us I think, Maria, is going to come down to what I said which is how can we ensure that we stay focused on building technologies that are relevant in helping our customers.

BARTIROMO: Satya, it's great to see you today. Thanks so much. And congratulations to you.

NADELLA: Thank you so much, Maria.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: We'll be right back. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. As we told you earlier, Goldman Sachs announced that David Solomon will take over for Lloyd Blankfein as CEO beginning October 1. Nicole Petallides is on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange with details looking at the stock. Nicole, good morning.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria. So it's finally official, I mean, David Solomon has been speculated to be the succession to Lloyd Blankfein in this top role particularly after the Goldman co-President Harvey Schwartz was out. And so now, he is going to take the helm on October 1st. He will be the third Goldman CEO since it went public in 1999. Of course, Hank Paulson who have gone on to be treasury secretary under George W. Bush, then Lloyd Blankfein and now David Soloman. Veteran investment banker will be taking over on October 1st. Now we're also -- by the way, he's also a D.J., that was another underlying story on his spare time which I thought was really cute in Miami, New York, and Bahamas. Let's take a look also at the numbers. You can see that the stock is down about a quarter of a percent. They did beat on profit and revenue. Revenue was listed by fixed income where they're not able to make it as the trading revenue clients are just a little spooked by the sharp price moves and so the strength certainly with investment banking and that was a winner. Johnson & Johnson, that is up right now after a beat strong dollar did hurt, defending itself in the talc issues. And last but not least, you are seeing UnitedHealth to the downside. The premiums missed and also medical loss ratio missed estimates but they did raise a forecast and did have some good numbers but a couple of misses weighing on the stock. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right. Stock down almost two percent UnitedHealth. Thank you, Nicole. Coming up. Amazon prime day starts with a glitch. Problems with the retail giant's Web site. Shoppers searching for deals later this hour. Then there is, Bryce Harper making an epic comeback. The highlights from last night's Home Run Derby coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Trade tensions escalating in the United States. Filing complaints against trading partners including Canada, China, the European Union. This after lawsuits were filed against the U.S. through the World Trade Organization over the steel and aluminum tariffs. Joining us right now is Ian Bremmer, President of the Eurasia Group and GZERO Media. Ian, great to see you this morning.

IAN BREMMER, PRESIDENT, EURASIA GROUP: Hi, Maia. Good morning to you.

BARTIROMO: What progress is being made on the trade front? Where are you in this trade dispute whether if it would with China or our allies on aluminum and steel?

BREMMER: So far, as you say, we have a dueling suits that have been put in place with the World Trade Organization. The the good news is that for those that were saying that there is draft, you know, sort of order going around from -- in the White House saying that Trump wants to withdraw the United States from the WTO, that was never feasible in terms of Congress. And it was never something that the Trump administration in any had a consensus in moving towards. They are using the WTO as the allies are, as China is and if this ends up getting resolved by the established multilateral trade organization over years, that's a much better place to be than unfettered escalation on trade.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Ian, it's Dagen McDowell. The commerce department under President Trump is studying this potential tariff on automobile imports into the United States, maybe 20 percent, maybe higher. They're looking at it right now. I believe there is a hearing even later this week. Do you think that just ultimately gets tabled because again they would try to argue that it's a -- that auto imports are risk to our national security potentially which just seems ludicrous.

BREMMER: Yes. But it seems ludicrous to make that argument for steel and aluminum with say the Canadians but they still made it. So, I mean, the fact is that you have a regulation and you've got people that are looking to find any way to press forward with a political posture that they want to pursue. Look, we know that when you talk to CEOs and businesspeople in the U.S., it's not the Helsinki meeting between Trump and Putin that they're worried about, they're worried about Trump's stance on trade. And they certainly believe and it's a -- it's true that if we press forward with these automotive tariffs that you're going to see, a significant hit to American workers, a significant hit to a lot of these American businesses.

BARTIROMO: By the way, Kevin Brady said that, he said that that's' going to show up in the economic numbers later this year, Jon.

HILSENRATH: Well, you know, you raised Helsinki and I want to -- I want to ask you about that. The President goes to Europe and he calls the European allies foes and then turns to Helsinki and has a pretty compatible interaction with Putin. How do you think America's European allies are looking at that Helsinki meeting and how does that shape the way they're going to respond to our trade stance and the challenge that the President is putting in front of them on autos and all these other goods?

BREMMER: Well, look, I mean, to be clear, it was very strange when Trump referred to the E.U. as a foe but then after that, he said China is also a foe, Russia is also a foe. So, the problem is that Trump clearly has a better set of relationships personally with authoritarian leaders around the world like Erdogan who he fist bumps at the NATO Summit in front of everyone else. Like Kim Jong-un, like Putin then he does with a lot of the allies. So obviously, the toxicity of the transatlantic relations, despite the fact that we have much closer relationships is a problem. On the other side, you look at Putin, it's very clear that Trump wants a better relationship with Putin. It's also very clear he's not going to get one. There is a reason why Trump spent over two hours with Putin in private and not with his advisories. It's not because he was worried that the advisers were going to say something out of turn that was more hawkish. Those advisers don't say boo unless Trump turns to them and says Mr. Pompeo, Mike, do you want to comment and say something, right? The issue is they don't agree with him. They have a harder line policy on Russia as the Republican Party does and they would have leaked like crazy if they were in that room. U.S. sanctions against Russia are still in place and there are harder line than they were under Obama. U.S. defense spending is up. Trump didn't say anything on recognition of Crimea, he didn't suspend NATO or U.S. military activities in the Baltics. He certainly didn't say we're going to take U.S. troops out of Syria. So as embarrassing as yesterday was from the perspective the of American President standing on the stage and providing moral equivalency with President Trump -- Putin, we need to recognize that the -- that actually U.S. policy towards Russia under the Trump administration is likely to be harder line at the end of 2018 than it was today.

(CROSSTALK)

HILSENRATH: Do you think we dial up --

BARTIROMO: That's a really good point.

HILSENRATH: Do you think we dial up sanctions on the Russians? We did it earlier this year when previous allegations of interference in our elections came out. Do we take these latest Mueller allegations and add to the sanction list?

BREMMER: I think we do. I think that Congress will continue to move in that direction as we see evidence -- intelligence evidence of the Russians engaged in the creation of more fake accounts and disinformation and cyberattacks around the midterm elections. Certainly in terms of cyberattacks against American critical infrastructure which is the single piece I was most concerned that Trump did not bring up publicly. It's the one that's the greatest danger in area of confrontation between the two countries. Congress is not backing off from that, Trump's own advisers are not backing off unless they all resign, there's no question that's where most of the Republican Party across the board is heading this year. I think we will see tougher sanctions, another round that comes down from the Americans against Russia later this year irrespective of whether that's what Trump wants or not.

BARTIROMO: That's what Jon Hilsenrath actually said earlier. Yes. That's a really good point, Ian. Thanks so much for joining us this morning, Ian.

BREMMER: My pleasure, guys.

BARTIROMO: Good to see. Ian Bremmer there. Coming up. President Trump headed to the Hill to discuss tax reform 2.0. We'll head to Washington, D.C. as well for all the details next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Tuesday morning, everybody, thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Tuesday, July 17th, your top stories right now 8:31 on the east coast. Trade tensions taking a backseat as investors are focused on earnings season today. Futures are indicating a fractionally lower opening for the broader averages. It's going to a big week for second-quarter reports, and we've already heard from three Dow components this morning. In Europe, this morning, markets are lower across the board, take a look, as you see, the FT-100 right around even, the CAC Quarante is down a third of a percent in Paris, and the DAX Index is down a fraction in Germany. In Asia overnight, mixed performances there as well. The one best performer was Japan, Nikkei Average up half a percent.

Amazon Prime Day starts with a glitch. Problems with the retail giant's Web site as shoppers search for deals later this hour. Plus, Jeff Bezos becomes the richest man alive. Details on the jaw-dropping net worth of the Amazon founder. And then, Bryce Harper staging an epic comeback in this year's Major League Baseball home run derby.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: There it is! Centerfield, and Bryce Harper has thrown his bat in the air, and won the 2018 T-Mobile home run derby.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: More of the highlights as we head live to Nationals Park in Washington, D.C., coming up. But, first, President Trump is putting another round of tax reforms on the fast track. Kristina Partsinevelos is in Washington this morning with all the details. Kristina, good morning.

KRISTINA PARTSINEVELOS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Good morning. That is Tax Reform 2.0. That's what they're calling it. You have some Republicans that are going to be meeting with the President this afternoon. What they're going to expect to some changes from the first set of tax cuts that happened about a year ago. What am I talking about changes? They were, we know, the corporate tax rate went from 35 percent to 21 percent. We know individual tax rates changed for the vast majority of Americans.

And I'd like to highlight just two income brackets. You have those that made around $38,000 to about $82,000, they saw their tax bracket dropped from 25 percent to 22 percent. However, if you're also, you know, making a little bit more money over $500,000, you saw your tax rate drop from 39.6 percent to 37 percent as well. So, both sides of the income brackets -- for across the board, they did benefit from these tax cuts. The problem is these individual tax cuts are set to expire in 2025. President Trump weighed in, listen to what he had to say about these tax cuts.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We're doing a phase two, we'll be doing it probably on October, maybe a little sooner than that. And it will be more of a middleclass. We did a lot for the middleclass but this will be even more aimed at the middleclass. One of the things we're thinking about is bringing the 21 percent down to 20, and then, for the most part, the rest of it would go right to the middleclass.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

PARTSINEVELOS: And what we know is Tuesday, they want to extend these individual tax rates, there's possibility about having universal savings account. There's also talk about small businesses and how small businesses can help retirement plans, specifically, encouraging small employers to offer retirement savings programs as well as annuities that would turn workers' savings into a guaranteed annual income. I know, Maria, you spoke on Wall Street to Kevin Brady, he's the chairman of the tax rating committee, and he also weighed in about how this could be beneficial to future growth in the American economy. Listen in.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. KEVIN BRADY (R), TEXAS: President Trump's tax cuts and reforms was about changing the economic direction of the country for the better, 2.0 is about changing the culture in Washington, where we don't wait 30 years between fixing the tax code, we get better every year, we continue to lead the rest of the world here. And so, you're going to see, I think, permanence of the middleclass cuts and the small business cuts will be the centerpiece of this. And people, I think, overlook the growth impact long term. That alone could help create a million and a half new jobs in America, continue to raise paychecks significantly in the long term. So, that will be the centerpiece of it. We're working with the President on the rest of the elements of 2.0.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

PARTSINEVELOS: So, Kevin Brady did highlight that they want to make it permanent. That's going to be the huge obstacle within the House because a lot of people have discussed, how high the deficit has ballooned because of these tax cuts. So, they're going to need about 60 votes and a lot of even Republicans have voiced some unease regarding this deficit. They want to push this forward before midterms as well. Maria?

BARTIROMO: Yes. How do you pay for it? The question keeps coming up. Kristina, thank you.

PARTSINEVELOS: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Kristina Partsinevelos. Let's turn to North Korea's nuclear ambitions hours after the Helsinki summit with Russia's President. President Trump revealed that Vladimir Putin will help the United States deal with North Korea and nuclear weapons. Here's what the President told Sean Hannity last night.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: You know, if look at Russia and the United States, that's 90 percent of the nuclear weapons. And --

(CROSSTALK)

TRUMP: -- doing something and working on other countries. And he also said he wants to be very helpful with North Korea. We're doing well with North Korea, we have time. There's no rush. You know, it's been going on for many years.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining me now is the former deputy defense secretary under George W. Bush and former ambassador to Indonesia, Paul Wolfowitz. Ambassador, good to see you this morning, thanks very much for joining us.

PAUL WOLFOWITZ, FORMER UNITED STATES AMBASSADOR TO INDONESIA: Nice to be with you.

BARTIROMO: Your reaction to what you just heard?

WOLFOWITZ: Look, we've been dealing with the North Korea issue for many years. I thought the whole idea was to try to get it behind us then to do it reasonably quickly. I'm worried that we're getting now mired in this strategic patience of waiting step-by-step and the North Koreans will continue to extract more and more as we go.

BARTIROMO: So, what should the President do then at this point? I mean, it was pretty historic that they met. We thought that we would see more progress. Are we seeing progress?

WOLFOWITZ: It seems to me we're not seeing progress. If anything, things seem to be going backward in terms of what the North Koreans are saying when they denounce the Secretary of State as a gangster after their meetings with him, and we're trying to pretend the meetings were fine. There's something wrong there. You know, in his own book, President Trump wrote years ago that in negotiating, it's important to know when to walk away, otherwise you start to seem desperate. And I worry that we may be starting to seem too eager for an agreement, and that's a bad way to get there.

BARTIROMO: That's interesting. And your thoughts on the Helsinki meeting, and the -- and the press conference with Putin?

WOLFOWITZ: Well, of course, we don't know much about the meeting except the press conference. But the press conference by itself is very important. And I hate to say this, but I think -- well, I don't hate to say this part, Putin is a classic KGB bully, with former President Bush, he even showed him his big Russian wolfhound and said, see, bigger, faster, stronger than your little scotch terrier. That's the kind of man he is, and I think, Americans often make the mistake, and I think maybe President Trump made this mistake, of thinking the way to improve relations with someone like that is to be nice to them. They just interpret that as weakness.

We have a lot of business to do with Russia, it's true. We could do with a better relationship, we could do with less close relationship between Russia and China, but that's not come -- going to come about by having Putin underestimate us and I'm afraid if the tone of the private meeting was like the press conference, where Putin dismissively said, what makes you think after Trump had said everything changed four hours ago, Putin dismissively says, why do you think we trust one another? It doesn't bode well.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

WOLFOWITZ: It reminds me, actually, Maria, of when President Kennedy met with, I guess, he was called General Secretary at the time, Nikita Khrushchev of the Soviet Union.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Right.

WOLFOWITZ: In Vienna in 1962, I think. It was interpreted as Kennedy being weak and was followed not so long afterwards by the Cuban missile crisis. You need to make sure he takes this deadly serious.

BARTIROMO: But what do you think about the policies? When you look at the policies that the U.S. has put in place, as it relates to Russia, whether it'd be sanctions, or troops, or you know, poking the Germans for having the gas pipeline deal? When you look at the policies versus the appeasement that we saw onstage yesterday, they're very different, aren't they?

WOLFOWITZ: They are somewhat different. They're not as different as they might be, but -- I think -- I mean, part of the problem, to be fair to the President, our President is that we're in a pretty deep hole in Syria and in Ukraine, and it's not clear how you dig out of that hole but we do need more pressure, and I think tougher sanctions would be appropriate. But I think something else we ought to be looking at is exposing what we know about Putin's corruption which I believe goes very, very deep. And the U.S. Justice Department has an ability to expose that which would be a huge pressure on Putin. We ought to think about doing something like that in my opinion.

BARTIROMO: Really interesting. Let me -- let me move over to the border crackdown. The National Guard which has been part of the stepped up immigration efforts has helped border agents arrest more than 10,000 illegal immigrants just since April. This comes as House GOP leaders are set to hold a vote tomorrow in support of all the Immigration and Customs Enforcement officers and denounce the calls by Democrats to abolish the ICE agencies. What do you make of the democratic attempt to abolish ICE? I mean, obviously, that stance has quicklu fallen apart.

WOLFOWITZ: I think you've just said it right there. We have to have immigration enforcement, we have to have border enforcement. I think sometimes ICE officials may get too aggressive about keeping people out of that treating immigrants -- or treating everyone as the illegal one whether they are or not. And certainly, we made, if nothing else, a mistake in this handling of the children that we separated from their parents. I think we're on the way to correcting that, and I think -- I think at the heart of this immigration issue, unfortunately, is a kind of canyon between the two sides, of one side saying, we really don't need any border enforcement at all, and I think that enrages most Americans who'll say, what the heck are you talking about here?

BARTIROMO: Yes, I totally agree with that. Let me ask you, Secretary, look across the world for us, where do you see the biggest risks in terms of foreign policy right now for the United States?

WOLFOWITZ: You know there's a big difference between the risks right now and the risks further in the future. Further -- and I'm going to go further in the future first because I think that is where China is potentially our biggest problem, it's a huge strong country that is clearly on an expansion in a kind of imperial mode. And that's the reason, by the way, in defense of trying to improve relations with Russia, to see if we can separate the two of them, instead of having them be close buddies which is where they are now. But I think in terms of immediate risks, North Korea is clearly one of the most serious ones. And I don't think we're making a progress with the speed that we thought we could, or that we should be able to do. So, I think we need to think about a tougher policy probably with North Korea than we've had.

BARTIROMO: What's the tougher policy? Like, what would be the most important policy this President could adopt?

WOLFOWITZ: Look, I think that regime is very vulnerable to economic sanctions. It's a miserable economy but they have to keep paying their policemen and their guards, and when they start running out of money to do that, I think it -- something that has to make them very nervous. And we went further with sanctions under this President than we have in the past, but I think there's still a long way that we could be going. So basically shut them out of the international financial system and to shut down people who are helping them like Chinese companies.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Yes, really good point. Ambassador, it's great to see you this morning, thanks very much for your insights.

WOLFOWITZ: You're very welcome.

BARTIROMO: We appreciate it very much. Paul Wolfowitz joining us there. Coming up, Amazon founder Jeff Bezos is crowned the richest man alive. Richest man in the planet. The details on the jaw-dropping net worth of the founder of Amazon. Then, Bryce Harper making an epic comeback, the highlights from last night's home run derby, coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. So, Amazon's Prime Day wasn't exactly ready for primetime. Deirdre Bolton is in New York City with all the details on that. Deirdre, hello, good morning to you.

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hello, Maria, good morning. I'm in front of Whole Foods which as you will remember, Amazon bought for upwards of $13 billion last year, but you mentioned these glitches for Prime Day which started yesterday at 3:00 p.m. Eastern Time, yes, for about three hours, Maria. If you were trying to buy something, you actually couldn't pay for it which I'm pretty sure is about the worst thing can happen to a retailer. Social media, you have this whole #goingaround which was #PrimeDayFail. But I want to let you know that statistically, it was still a win for Amazon even in those dicey three hours, shoppers have still spent more than 54 percent more in those first three hours than they did on Prime Day this time last year. So, you may wonder or for our viewers who may wonder, what exactly is Prime Day, this is the fourth annual run at it for Amazon, it equals Black Friday as far as the numbers go.

Amazon has more than a million deals today, Maria, they want you to buy Fire Stick, Echo Dot, that was the big seller last year. They also want you to buy groceries. They didn't buy Whole Foods for nothing. So, if you show up here, if you're an Amazon Prime Member who has not yet gotten a grocery deliver from Whole Foods, if you go today, you spend more than $10.00, you get $10.00 off of future order and another one as well. All of this, glitches included, we have to say have not hurt the founder and CEO, Jeff Bezos. He is the world's richest man, at least measured in modern U.S. dollars of 150 billion U.S. is his worth. The stock is up 55 percent this year, Maria, that has added $50 billion just to his pocket alone.

So, he has passed Bill Gates, of course, the founder of Microsoft. Jeff Bezos has also passed the Oracle of Omaha, Warren Buffett, he has passed Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook. And a lot of people somewhat critical of Jeff Bezos saying, OK, well, how come he isn't giving more of his money away, all of those other people that I mentioned obviously have plans in place. But he is working on building infrastructure in space, that has been the answer untold but that takes a lot of money. Maria?

BARTIROMO: That's incredible, Deirdre, $150 billion value -- net wealth of Jeff Bezos. Pretty incredible. Deirdre, thank you, we will be watching Amazon shares and where Bezos' wealth goes next. Can you believe that, you guys, $150 billion?

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Here's to Varney about to weigh -- and you predicted it. Once again, you predicted yesterday you said it was going to be a big day, and you've been positive on Amazon for some time.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: I remember, a half century ago, when I was brought up on the idea that if you are truly rich, you could live on the interest from the interest from your capital. I suspect that Mr. Bezos can live on the interest on the interest on the interest on the interest from his $150 billion, but I digress. Look, I think that big tech investors face a bit of a problem right now, can big techl keep on scoring 30, 40 percent increases in their profits and their revenue? That's a very tough row to hoe, but that's the situation as of now.

If you look at Netflix, which I consider a big name technology company, they're going to be down, what, 10, maybe 11 percent this morning because they missed their expectations, they missed their new subscribers. So, there's a big question here for all of big tech, is it the end of the road or should I buy more, or just do nothing and let it ride? Very interesting question today.

BARTIROMO: Well, maybe the expectations have to come in just a little. When you have expectations all the way up there, hard to have any room for error.

VARNEY: I hate expectations. You know what I feel about that.

BARTIROMO: Stu, we'll see you in 10 minutes.

VARNEY: You will.

BARTIROMO: I know you got a lot more on "VARNEY & COMPANY." Join Stuart top of the hour at 9:00 a.m. right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA. But first, Bryce Harper winning this year's home run derby. More of the highlights next as we head to Nationals Park in D.C.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Fireworks at the home run derby. Hometown hero, Bryce Harper, wowing the crowd as Washington, D.C., gets ready for tonight's all-star game. Connell McShane with the details from Nationals Park. Connell?

CONNELL MCSHANE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey, there, good morning, Maria, kind of fun to be here in Washington talking some baseball instead of politics for a change. 89th Major League Baseball all-star game will be tonight on the Fox broadcast network, and the first time they've had it here in D.C. since back in 1969 when it was the Senators, not the Nationals playing in this city. But as you said it, last night, a lot of fun with the home run derby. Let's take a look at some of the highlights, Bryce Harper, obviously with the favorite go again given the hometown guy and he came out dressed for the occasion with stars and stripes bandana. But I got to tell you, for Harper got a run from his -- for his money from the Cubs' Kyle Schwarber.

Now, Schwarber, the power left-handed hitter hit more than 20 home runs in the semi-final run of the derby and then in the final, he kind of set the pace. He went first, did Schwarber, and he put 18 on the board. So, Harper knew he had to make a good run at it. He got off to a slow start in the final. When Harper came up, his dad pitching too him, just couldn't get the rhythm. Took a time-out which you're allowed to do in the home run derby, kind of take a deep breath, set himself, and then he really got going on some kind of a run, and hit the game-winning home run with two hands in the air. The big celebration in front of the hometown crowd.

So, sometimes that's more exciting, Maria, than the game. We'll see how things go tonight but I know there was a lot of buzz here in the stadium for the derby last night. We'll have plenty more throughout the day (INAUDIBLE) the game is on Fox tonight, so we'll speak to some of the stars there (INAUDIBLE) Alex Rodriguez and others, and maybe a few surprise guests, so we'll see you throughout the day here from Nationals Park.

BARTIROMO: Awesome. Great coverage, Connell, thanks. We'll be tune in. Have fun, Connell McShane. Remember to watch the MLB All-Star game tonight at 8:00 p.m. Eastern on Fox. Coming up, we got final thoughts from this all-star panel. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Final thoughts from this all-star panel. Lindsey Bell?

BELL: I think Netflix -- we're getting a gift. This is a buying opportunity. They're spending more on content than anyone else, and I think they will bode guidance.

BARTIROMO: Wow. Even the stock is where it is. All right, Jon Hilsenrath?

HILSENRATH: 9:15 we're going to get really strong data on manufacturing sector. 10:00 a.m. we're going to have Jay Powell saying the economy is in great shape. Despite all of these angsts right now about what's happening on the trade front, the economy is in pretty good shape.

BARTIROMO: It sure is. And we're going to get a 4-1/2 percent number on GDP, you said.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: Right. That's the estimate from the Atlanta Feds for now. But the reason that there is so much optimism is because those tax cuts for corporations, they're permanent. Regardless of what the President says or does not say, that's something that companies can take to the banks.

BARTIROMO: And today, they're going to try to come up with Tax Plan 2.0 and make the individual cuts permanent.

MCDOWELL: Right. And maybe turn the attention to the economy and away from what happened in Helsinki.

HILSENRATH: I'm waiting for them to do something about the deficit. It's nice to have those tax-cuts but we've got very good --

(CROSSTALK)

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: Good luck.

BARTIROMO: Yes, good point. Thanks, everybody. Great show. Right to Varney we go. That'll do it for us. Have a great day, everybody. Here's Stuart. Stu?

VARNEY: Here I am, and good morning, Maria, and good morning, everyone.

END

urn:contentItem:5SV2-2T91-JBHT-D32N-00000-00Wal-Mart, Microsoft Take Aim At Amazon With Cloud Tech; Microsoft CEO Calls For A.I. Regulation Of Facial Recognition Technology2018-07-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:41ZLexisNexisWal-Mart, Microsoft Take Aim At Amazon With Cloud Tech; Microsoft CEO Calls For A.I. Regulation Of Facial Recognition TechnologyLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good Tuesday morning. Welcome back, everybody. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Tuesday, July 17th. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. They're not as different as they might be, but -- I think -- I mean, part of the problem, to be fair to the President, our President is that we're in a pretty deep hole in Syria and in Ukraine, and it's not clear how you dig out of that hole but we do need more pressure, and I think tougher sanctions would be appropriate. But I think something else we ought to be looking at is exposing what we know about Putin's corruption which I believe goes very, very deep. And the U.S. Justice Department has an ability to expose that which would be a huge pressure on Putin. We ought to think about doing something like that in my opinion.

BARTIROMO: Really interesting. Let me -- let me move over to the border crackdown. The National Guard which has been part of the stepped up immigration efforts has helped border agents arrest more than 10,000 illegal immigrants just since April. This comes as House GOP leaders are set to hold a vote tomorrow in support of all the Immigration and Customs Enforcement officers and denounce the calls by Democrats to abolish the ICE agencies. What do you make of the democratic attempt to abolish ICE? I mean, obviously, that stance has quicklu fallen apart.

WOLFOWITZ: I think you've just said it right there. We have to have immigration enforcement, we have to have border enforcement. I think sometimes ICE officials may get too aggressive about keeping people out of that treating immigrants -- or treating everyone as the illegal one whether they are or not. And certainly, we made, if nothing else, a mistake in this handling of the children that we separated from their parents. I think we're on the way to correcting that, and I think -- I think at the heart of this immigration issue, unfortunately, is a kind of canyon between the two sides, of one side saying, we really don't need any border enforcement at all, and I think that enrages most Americans who'll say, what the heck are you talking about here?

BARTIROMO: Yes, I totally agree with that. Let me ask you, Secretary, look across the world for us, where do you see the biggest risks in terms of foreign policy right now for the United States?

WOLFOWITZ: You know there's a big difference between the risks right now and the risks further in the future. Further -- and I'm going to go further in the future first because I think that is where China is potentially our biggest problem, it's a huge strong country that is clearly on an expansion in a kind of imperial mode. And that's the reason, by the way, in defense of trying to improve relations with Russia, to see if we can separate the two of them, instead of having them be close buddies which is where they are now. But I think in terms of immediate risks, North Korea is clearly one of the most serious ones. And I don't think we're making a progress with the speed that we thought we could, or that we should be able to do. So, I think we need to think about a tougher policy probably with North Korea than we've had.

BARTIROMO: What's the tougher policy? Like, what would be the most important policy this President could adopt?

WOLFOWITZ: Look, I think that regime is very vulnerable to economic sanctions. It's a miserable economy but they have to keep paying their policemen and their guards, and when they start running out of money to do that, I think it -- something that has to make them very nervous. And we went further with sanctions under this President than we have in the past, but I think there's still a long way that we could be going. So basically shut them out of the international financial system and to shut down people who are helping them like Chinese companies.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Yes, really good point. Ambassador, it's great to see you this morning, thanks very much for your insights.

WOLFOWITZ: You're very welcome.

BARTIROMO: We appreciate it very much. Paul Wolfowitz joining us there. Coming up, Amazon founder Jeff Bezos is crowned the richest man alive. Richest man in the planet. The details on the jaw-dropping net worth of the founder of Amazon. Then, Bryce Harper making an epic comeback, the highlights from last night's home run derby, coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. So, Amazon's Prime Day wasn't exactly ready for primetime. Deirdre Bolton is in New York City with all the details on that. Deirdre, hello, good morning to you.

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hello, Maria, good morning. I'm in front of Whole Foods which as you will remember, Amazon bought for upwards of $13 billion last year, but you mentioned these glitches for Prime Day which started yesterday at 3:00 p.m. Eastern Time, yes, for about three hours, Maria. If you were trying to buy something, you actually couldn't pay for it which I'm pretty sure is about the worst thing can happen to a retailer. Social media, you have this whole #goingaround which was #PrimeDayFail. But I want to let you know that statistically, it was still a win for Amazon even in those dicey three hours, shoppers have still spent more than 54 percent more in those first three hours than they did on Prime Day this time last year. So, you may wonder or for our viewers who may wonder, what exactly is Prime Day, this is the fourth annual run at it for Amazon, it equals Black Friday as far as the numbers go.

Amazon has more than a million deals today, Maria, they want you to buy Fire Stick, Echo Dot, that was the big seller last year. They also want you to buy groceries. They didn't buy Whole Foods for nothing. So, if you show up here, if you're an Amazon Prime Member who has not yet gotten a grocery deliver from Whole Foods, if you go today, you spend more than $10.00, you get $10.00 off of future order and another one as well. All of this, glitches included, we have to say have not hurt the founder and CEO, Jeff Bezos. He is the world's richest man, at least measured in modern U.S. dollars of 150 billion U.S. is his worth. The stock is up 55 percent this year, Maria, that has added $50 billion just to his pocket alone.

So, he has passed Bill Gates, of course, the founder of Microsoft. Jeff Bezos has also passed the Oracle of Omaha, Warren Buffett, he has passed Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook. And a lot of people somewhat critical of Jeff Bezos saying, OK, well, how come he isn't giving more of his money away, all of those other people that I mentioned obviously have plans in place. But he is working on building infrastructure in space, that has been the answer untold but that takes a lot of money. Maria?

BARTIROMO: That's incredible, Deirdre, $150 billion value -- net wealth of Jeff Bezos. Pretty incredible. Deirdre, thank you, we will be watching Amazon shares and where Bezos' wealth goes next. Can you believe that, you guys, $150 billion?

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Here's to Varney about to weigh -- and you predicted it. Once again, you predicted yesterday you said it was going to be a big day, and you've been positive on Amazon for some time.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: I remember, a half century ago, when I was brought up on the idea that if you are truly rich, you could live on the interest from the interest from your capital. I suspect that Mr. Bezos can live on the interest on the interest on the interest on the interest from his $150 billion, but I digress. Look, I think that big tech investors face a bit of a problem right now, can big techl keep on scoring 30, 40 percent increases in their profits and their revenue? That's a very tough row to hoe, but that's the situation as of now.

If you look at Netflix, which I consider a big name technology company, they're going to be down, what, 10, maybe 11 percent this morning because they missed their expectations, they missed their new subscribers. So, there's a big question here for all of big tech, is it the end of the road or should I buy more, or just do nothing and let it ride? Very interesting question today.

BARTIROMO: Well, maybe the expectations have to come in just a little. When you have expectations all the way up there, hard to have any room for error.

VARNEY: I hate expectations. You know what I feel about that.

BARTIROMO: Stu, we'll see you in 10 minutes.

VARNEY: You will.

BARTIROMO: I know you got a lot more on "VARNEY & COMPANY." Join Stuart top of the hour at 9:00 a.m. right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA. But first, Bryce Harper winning this year's home run derby. More of the highlights next as we head to Nationals Park in D.C.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Fireworks at the home run derby. Hometown hero, Bryce Harper, wowing the crowd as Washington, D.C., gets ready for tonight's all-star game. Connell McShane with the details from Nationals Park. Connell?

CONNELL MCSHANE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey, there, good morning, Maria, kind of fun to be here in Washington talking some baseball instead of politics for a change. 89th Major League Baseball all-star game will be tonight on the Fox broadcast network, and the first time they've had it here in D.C. since back in 1969 when it was the Senators, not the Nationals playing in this city. But as you said it, last night, a lot of fun with the home run derby. Let's take a look at some of the highlights, Bryce Harper, obviously with the favorite go again given the hometown guy and he came out dressed for the occasion with stars and stripes bandana. But I got to tell you, for Harper got a run from his -- for his money from the Cubs' Kyle Schwarber.

Now, Schwarber, the power left-handed hitter hit more than 20 home runs in the semi-final run of the derby and then in the final, he kind of set the pace. He went first, did Schwarber, and he put 18 on the board. So, Harper knew he had to make a good run at it. He got off to a slow start in the final. When Harper came up, his dad pitching too him, just couldn't get the rhythm. Took a time-out which you're allowed to do in the home run derby, kind of take a deep breath, set himself, and then he really got going on some kind of a run, and hit the game-winning home run with two hands in the air. The big celebration in front of the hometown crowd.

So, sometimes that's more exciting, Maria, than the game. We'll see how things go tonight but I know there was a lot of buzz here in the stadium for the derby last night. We'll have plenty more throughout the day (INAUDIBLE) the game is on Fox tonight, so we'll speak to some of the stars there (INAUDIBLE) Alex Rodriguez and others, and maybe a few surprise guests, so we'll see you throughout the day here from Nationals Park.

BARTIROMO: Awesome. Great coverage, Connell, thanks. We'll be tune in. Have fun, Connell McShane. Remember to watch the MLB All-Star game tonight at 8:00 p.m. Eastern on Fox. Coming up, we got final thoughts from this all-star panel. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Final thoughts from this all-star panel. Lindsey Bell?

BELL: I think Netflix -- we're getting a gift. This is a buying opportunity. They're spending more on content than anyone else, and I think they will bode guidance.

BARTIROMO: Wow. Even the stock is where it is. All right, Jon Hilsenrath?

HILSENRATH: 9:15 we're going to get really strong data on manufacturing sector. 10:00 a.m. we're going to have Jay Powell saying the economy is in great shape. Despite all of these angsts right now about what's happening on the trade front, the economy is in pretty good shape.

BARTIROMO: It sure is. And we're going to get a 4-1/2 percent number on GDP, you said.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: Right. That's the estimate from the Atlanta Feds for now. But the reason that there is so much optimism is because those tax cuts for corporations, they're permanent. Regardless of what the President says or does not say, that's something that companies can take to the banks.

BARTIROMO: And today, they're going to try to come up with Tax Plan 2.0 and make the individual cuts permanent.

MCDOWELL: Right. And maybe turn the attention to the economy and away from what happened in Helsinki.

HILSENRATH: I'm waiting for them to do something about the deficit. It's nice to have those tax-cuts but we've got very good --

(CROSSTALK)

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: Good luck.

BARTIROMO: Yes, good point. Thanks, everybody. Great show. Right to Varney we go. That'll do it for us. Have a great day, everybody. Here's Stuart. Stu?

VARNEY: Here I am, and good morning, Maria, and good morning, everyone.

urn:contentItem:5YD0-HTC1-JBJN-M07S-00000-00Walmart offers lessons for market-based health reform2020-03-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:41ZLexisNexisWalmart offers lessons for market-based health reformSteven Greenhut


When I needed new glasses, I went to an optometrist for an exam, picked out some dorky black frames, paid my portion and my insurance picked up the rest. Then, by chance, I walked into one of those ubiquitous Walmart optometry centers and realized I could have had the exam and the glasses for little more than the price of the copay. That speaks volumes about our current health system.


When a third party — insurance or government, for instance — pays for something, the prices escalate. What’s the first thing an auto body shop asks when you take in your car to repair the fender? “Is this an insurance job?” If it is, the price will be higher than if you’re paying for it yourself. I never asked the price of my appendix surgery last year, nor did I care. Blue Cross paid the tab.
It’s far worse when government is the default payer, given there are no serious controls on costs. There only are two ways to divvy up resources: pricing or rationing. As economist Thomas Sowell explains, “What everyone wants adds up to more than there is. Market economies deal with this problem by confronting individuals with the costs of producing what they want, and letting those individuals make their own trade-offs….”
Healthcare is tough because everyone needs access to life-saving surgeries and drugs. Unfortunately, our policymakers look at the problem through the wrong lens. Many seek to upend an insurance-based system that works remarkably well (despite the high prices) and replace it with government-run systems that will spend the nation into penury and lead to long waits for common services (rationing).
Instead of starting from scratch, policymakers ought to fill in the gaps — meet the needs of those people who are falling through the cracks of the current system. One idea goes back to that example in the first paragraph. No one will ever head to Walmart for a kidney transplant, but retail companies and profit-based clinics certainly can offer high-quality, lower-level services – and impose market discipline in a sector that sorely needs it.
Walmart announced last year that it intends to provide clinics that offer low-cost X-rays, lab work, checkups and dentistry, according to a recent CNBC article. “We’re going to have a consumer revolution,” former Apple CEO John Sculley told the news network. “Why? Because if the Walmart tests are successful, and I suspect they will be, people will be able to go in and get these kinds of health services at a lower cost than if they had health insurance.”
One of the biggest flaws of Obamacare is that it imposed myriad healthcare mandates, requiring health policies to cover every manner of treatment and service that politicians deemed necessary. For instance, it’s silly for an insurance company to be forced to provide my wife and I, who are in our late 50s, with birth-control coverage.
In other areas, we choose insurance based on our specific needs. I use insurance to protect against financially catastrophic events, not to cover minor services that I can pay for myself. Other people have different needs and priorities.
Scully explained that the big tech firms “realize that this is the largest remaining industry that has not been revolutionized by modern technologies that has transformed every other big industry in the United States.” That’s because health care, and health insurance, is dominated by government regulation and subsidy. Private companies can’t revolutionize industries that are encrusted with Byzantine rules — and where price signals can’t work their magic.
In particular, occupational licensing rules, which are enforced by entrenched industries that want to keep out the competition, make it difficult to innovate. That’s true especially in healthcare industries. One reason the gig economy has been so successful is these emergent companies have created newfangled ways to circumvent competition-stifling policies that lock inefficient systems into place. Thank goodness for clever work-arounds.
If you look at prices over time, you’ll find that consumer buying power has improved dramatically in industries that have the fewest government regulations. I remember when my parents bought our first color television in 1973 for $470. I still recall the price because it was such a major purchase, the equivalent of around $2,700 in today’s dollars. I recently bought a fancy smart TV for 300 bucks — and chose among dozens of options.
When products or services largely are immune to market pressure (because government provides, subsidizes or heavily regulates them), inflation levels are daunting. California public schools never have enough money even though per-pupil spending has soared. That’s true for every public service. College tuition has soared. A day doesn’t go by without some politician complaining about skyrocketing healthcare prices. Don’t you think there’s a connection?
Sculley predicts Walmart-style health clinics can lead to a “consumer revolution.” That’s no doubt true — provided government gets out of the way and allows it to happen.

urn:contentItem:5WSD-P091-F03R-N1BM-00000-00Walmart's Crypto Unlikely to be as Regulatory Controversial as Libra2019-08-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:41ZLexisNexisWalmart's Crypto Unlikely to be as Regulatory Controversial as LibraNick Chong

Aug 09, 2019( Blockonomi: https://blockonomi.com Delivered by Newstex) At long last, regulators are taking note of the cryptocurrency space. The launch of Libra proverbially lit a fire under the derrieres of the world's governments, many of which have disregarded Bitcoin and other digital assets, despite their massive bouts of growth over the past decade.While Libra is truly an innovation that has the potential to revolutionize the economy, governments have quickly expressed distaste towards the project, which is also backed by PayPal, Visa, Booking Holdings, Coinbase[1], and more.President Donald Trump vehemently came out against the proposed cryptocurrency, perpetuating his anti-Facebook (and anti-big tech) stance, as did the Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin.But interestingly, experts say that similar projects from other behemoths of corporations will not face as much regulatory heat. Walmart Files Patent Mentioning 'Cryptocurrency' Last week, Walmart quietly filed a patent to the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office.

While the retailer likely files dozens, if not hundreds of patents each and every month, the content of this certain patent was of interest to the cryptocurrency industry.The patent is for a 'system and method of digital currency via blockchain', which would back a presumably U.S. Dollar-backed stablecoin that can be deployed to Walmart's facets. One feature mentioned would be for the cryptocurrency, let's call it WalmartCoin, to be used as a potential reward in Walmart's customer savings programs.It is important to note that there's a chance that this patent is nothing more than a corporate strategy or marketing ploy. Over the years, firms like Nike, Kodak, and Amazon have filed blockchain-related patents or made references to cryptocurrencies, but have yet to actually announce any intentions to make a bonafide sortie into the industry. A Controversial Play? With there being so much pressure on the cryptocurrency space, many have been left wondering if Walmart's potential project will end up just like Libra — in the scopes of the world's most powerful entities, governments, and bodies.According to a research note obtained by Bloomberg[2] from Cowen, a financial services firm, it isn't all too likely. In fact, analysts at the firm suggest that as WalmartCoin doesn't share the same 'global intentions' as Libra, which is slated to be rolled out to dozens of countries and backed by a basket of sovereign currencies, it may actually strike a chord with some politicians in America.Cowen wrote that Walmart may 'especially appeal to Democrats', which are looking to promote the provision of financial services to the unbanked/underbanked. Not Walmart's First Blockchain Rodeo If the retail giant ends up launching a cryptocurrency, that won't be its first rodeo in the blockchain industry. Far from, in fact.As reported by Blockonomi earlier this year[3], Walmart's division in China, which presides over 424 retail stores and a handful of corporate warehouses in the nation, joined hands with VeChain. Through this partnership, unveiled at a Chinese conference for product safety and traceability, the consortium is tracking an unnamed 23 'product lines' through blockchain.By the end of 2020 — just under 18 months away — the collective wants to trace 50% of packaged fresh meat, 40% of packaged vegetables, and 12.5% of packaged seafood that Walmart China sells through blockchain technologies.The idea is to integrate a 'traceability strategy for products and pioneer the large-scale application of blockchain traceability.' that will give consumers some peace of mind when purchasing products, which is especially important in China, where fake products are rampant and actually dangerous.Walmart has entered similar initiatives around the world, mostly teaming up with the extremely blockchain-friendly technology giant IBM to test out blockchain supply chain and food safety solutions. https://blockonomi.com/out/coinbasebutton   https://blockonomi.com/out/etoro eToro Risk Warning: 66% of retail investor accounts lose money when trading CFDs with this provider. urn:contentItem:60RR-S761-F021-62T0-00000-00Walmart targets Amazon2020-09-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:41ZLexisNexisWalmart targets AmazonTaking Stock

Which one of the big tech companies is in the strongest market position? Many investors would choose Apple (US:AAPL) based on its proprietary hardware and status as the world's most recognisable brand. However, there are signs that some middle-income consumers have become less inclined to meet the premium prices charged by the group. It could also be argued that Apple is overly reliant on sales through its flagship retail stores.

And because its products are essentially incompatible with other devices, punters are compelled to exclusively purchase Apple apps or accessories. Apple may have enjoyed an almost cult-like status when Steve Jobs was alive, but research from professional services group Accenture indicates that brand loyalty is becoming a more elusive quality.

Like any other business, the trillion-dollar enterprise was never invulnerable, but it is debatable whether the brand cache is quite as strong it used to be, even though the shares remain as well supported as they have ever been.

Likewise, Google parent group Alphabet (US:GOOGL), which has just posted a 52-week high. Short of some revolutionary technological innovation, it is difficult to imagine how any competitor would be able to arrest the group's growing dominance in online search, video content sharing, and internet advertising markets.

The group has achieved its primacy in these markets through its early mastery of search algorithms, in addition to the widespread adoption of its Android mobile operating system, which accounts for around three-quarters of global usage.

The sheer volume of data gathered through its numerous products and services - many of which were the result of M&A - provides a key competitive advantage. However, this is now being viewed as a double-edged sword, particularly as machine learning becomes ever more advanced. The extent and application of the group's user data harvesting - and its blatant obfuscation and secrecy - has unnerved many end users and could conceivably draw a much stronger response from regulators going forward.

There are any number of business practices that have been brought into question. For example, the proliferation of paid links from advertisers at the top of the Google search page means that a much greater proportion of users never access the open web at all, instead opting for information provided by Google itself. There is a clear conflict of interest assuming the search engine's primary function is to provide dispassionate analysis of the site's user preferences. Little wonder that nearly every state regulator in the US has their sights trained on the tech giant.

Though both Apple and Alphabet enjoy market-leading positions, it is conceivable that the former's advantage could be eroded through intensified competition, while the latter tech heavyweight could eventually fall foul of antitrust regulators. It has been posited that a Democrat victory in the upcoming US election would reduce the chances of enforced break-ups given vice-presidential candidate Senator Kamala Harris's close links to Silicon Valley.

Like Alphabet, Amazon (US:AMZN) has thrived during the pandemic, but until recently you would have thought the threat of antitrust regulators would have posed the principal threat to the business. But midway through this month will see the launch of Walmart+, the eponymous retailer's answer to the Amazon Prime subscription service.

Walmart (US:WMT) is one of the few retailers with the financial clout and logistical capacity to make a sizeable dent in Amazon's volumes, at least in the US, where the latter accounts for around 40 per cent of online retail sales, largely the result of the delivery benefits linked to the Prime service.

The monthly subscription rate for Walmart+ at $12.95 is broadly in line with that of Amazon. For that outlay, customers can expect same-day delivery on more than 160,000 items, including tech, toys, household essentials, and groceries. There is also a 'Scan & Go' option, which will enable members to significantly speed up the shopping process at Walmart's bricks-and-mortar outlets. There are no streaming services available, and limited pricing benefits given that the retailers already price-match each other. But members will be entitled to receive fuel discounts at Walmart's petrol stations. It is thought that the discounting may eventually extend to Walmart pharmacies.

The new service is essentially a rebranding of the existing Delivery Unlimited service, albeit with a few bells and whistles attached. This is not the first time that Walmart has tried to replicate Amazon's success in the online retail space, but you are left wondering whether the enhanced online offering is aimed at preserving Walmart's existing customer base, rather than eating into Amazon's outsized share of the market.

urn:contentItem:5TBY-7011-F00X-J2SW-00000-00Walmart Transforms With Flipkart; Vestager Takes Aim at Big Tech -- ICYMI2018-09-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:41ZLexisNexisWalmart Transforms With Flipkart; Vestager Takes Aim at Big Tech -- ICYMIMichael Brown

Here's what you need to know now for Wednesday, Sept. 26.


For those of you still calling Walmart a pure-play retailer, you may want to check again. The company is day-by-day, deal-by-deal, turning itself into a powerhouse in e-commerce and a global dynamo. Walmart-owned Flipkart, India's e-commerce market-leader that Walmart acquired for more than $16 billion just a few months ago, has inked a deal to acquire Israeli startup Upstream Commerce. The price was not disclosed. However, the deal provides an exit for Israel-based investor YL Ventures, which has backed the pricing technology provider with seed money and at least two institutional rounds. It is seen as an important buy for Flipkart in its competition with Amazon in India, as well as potentially for the wider Walmart group, writes The Deal's Jonathan Braude in London. Upstream Commerce's cloud-based technology serves a wide range of customers from pet-care products groups Nestle Purina Petcare Co.and Petco Animal Supplies Inc.to home improvement retailer Lowe's Co. and French power tools retailer Debonix, German percussion instruments seller Meinl Musikinstrumente and Singaporean online grocer RedMart.


We talked about how the U.S. regulators are changing their stance on big technology and today, it was Europe's turn. European antitrust boss and Silicon Valley bête noire Margrethe Vestager held forth on the challenges of regulating Amazon, Google, Apple and an increasingly powerful tech sector at a New York conference Wednesday. "It is important for us to understand what is the new big," Vestager, the Commissioner for Competition for the European Commission, explained at Bloomberg LP's global business forum. Regulators have to weigh network effects, the ability to harness big data, low marginal costs and other factors that can tip the competitive scale, she observed. "I think our principles are fine because they are about human nature," she said. Most recently, Vestager opened a preliminary investigation into Amazon's e-commerce marketplace.


Markets Today: Stocks fell in late trading to end the day lower Wednesday after the Federal Reserve boosted interest rates by 25 basis points, marking the central bank's third tightening of 2018. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and other key indices gave up earlier gains ahead of the widely expected rate hike. The Dow Industrials ended off 0.4% at 26,385. The S&P 500 lost 0.3% to 2,906 and the Nasdaq dropped 0.2% to 7,990.

At the time of publication, Action Alerts PLUS , which Cramer co-manages as a charitable trust, was long GOOGL, AAPL and AMZN.

urn:contentItem:5H7K-RGK1-F05M-K26H-00000-00Wal-Mart wants to take on Amazon with drone delivery2015-10-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:41ZLexisNexisWal-Mart wants to take on Amazon with drone deliveryAshley Stewart

Two of the world's largest retailers are going head-to-head on drone delivery.

Wal-Mart (NYSE: WMT) is positioning itself to take on Amazon (Nasdaq: AMZN) on the futuristic technology after the company on Monday applied to the Federal Aviation Administration for permission to test drones for home delivery.

The world's largest retailer has been testing the aircraft indoors for months, Reuters reports, and now wants the go-ahead to test the drones outdoors.

"Drones have a lot of potential to further connect our vast network of stores, distribution centers, fulfillment centers and transportation fleet," Wal-Mart spokesman Dan Toporek told Reuters. "There is a Walmart within five miles of 70 percent of the U.S. population, which creates some unique and interesting possibilities for serving customers with drones."

U.S. regulators earlier this year gave Amazon permission to begin testing delivery drones outdoors, but under tight restrictions. The Seattle online retailer is testing drones indoors somewhere in Washington and has been lobbying aggressively for broad regulatory approval.

Amazon, which calls its drone program Prime Air, has been working for years to speed up delivery service. Amazon is even hiring executives to oversee a complete revamp of its delivery system. The company launched its Prime Now one- and two-hour service in Seattle this fall. Drone delivery, according to the company, would allow for 30-minute delivery.

Other companies including Googleare testing drone programs, but when the first drone delivered a package in the U.S. earlier this year with FAA approval, none of the big tech companies were involved.
